Framework.Question: Anthony is a project manager in a software consulting organization. His project has a high level of change associated with it. There is active and ongoing stakeholder involvement. This means he is probably working with a(n):
Framework.Explanation: Projects with adaptive life cycles are intended to respond to high levels of change and require ongoing stakeholder engagement. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 131

Framework.Question: The development life cycle type in which the deliverable is produced through a series of iterations that successively add functionality within a predetermined time frame is called:
Framework.Explanation: In an incremental life cycle, the deliverable is produced through a series of iterations that successively add functionality within a predetermined time frame. The deliverable contains the necessary and sufficient capability to be considered complete only after the final iteration. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 19

Framework.Question: Mariam has reached the end of the design phase of a construction project. She decides to call a "phase end review" for obtaining authorization to close the design phase and initiate the next phase (i.e., execution phase) of her project. The functional manager disagrees with her suggestion. He wants a "kill point" to formally end the design phase of the project. In this context, Mariam should:
Framework.Choice 1: A) Disagree with the functional manager because she knows that phase end reviews should be used at the end of each phase of the project.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Agree with the functional manager as kill point is a phase-end review.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Escalate this issue to the project sponsor.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Take advice from a senior project manager about what should actually be done at the end of each phase of the project.
Framework.Explanation: A phase gate, is held at the end of a phase. Depending on the organization, industry, or type of work, phase gates may be referred to by other terms such as, phase review, stage gate, kill point, and phase entrance or phase exit. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 21

Framework.Question: Shawn works as a project manager for a construction company. His company regularly builds teams to create products for clients. When the product is delivered, the team is dissolved and assigned to other projects. What kind of organizational structure of his company?
Framework.Explanation: Table 2-1. Organizational Structure and its influences on projects, Information Technology Project Management, page 50

Framework.Question: You have just been hired to work in an ongoing project in which the functional managers are responsible for arranging work groups while the project manager is responsible for managing the project budget. What organizational structure type is being used in such project?
Framework.Explanation: Table 2-1. Organizational Structure and its influences on projects, Information Technology Project Management, page 50

Framework.Question: You have been appointed as a full-time manager for a smart watches production project. You are reporting to the functional manager of the integration track who will manage the project budget. What type of organization structure are you part of?
Framework.Explanation: The role of the project manager is mostly part time in organic and functional organization structure. Thus, A and D are not correct. In Matrix-Strong organization, the project manager is required full time, but at the same time it is generally the project manager who takes care of the budget so, C is also not correct. The roles are mixed in hybrid organization, and the above scenario is an ideal example of Hybrid organization structure. Consequently, among all choices provided B is the best answer. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 47

Framework.Question: Your team members told you that they are overloaded with many tasks. They are saying that they have many tasks assigned to them besides the main tasks in the project. You promised them that you would clear the overloaded tasks. You are a project manager in:
Framework.Explanation: It is clear that the project manager has full power to remove the overloaded tasks from team members, and because team members have many tasks besides the main tasks in the project so, it is a strong organization.

Framework.Question: William is managing a manufacturing project. His project team members have a dual reporting structure: they report to him and also to the functional manager. The project team members are expecting to do the project work in addition to the department work. Which form of organization is William working in?
Framework.Explanation: Matrix Organization. Any organizational structure in which the project manager shares responsibility with the functional managers for assigning priorities and for directing the work of persons assigned to the project. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 710

Framework.Question: Where should the project manager obtain the initial cost-benefit analysis?
Framework.Explanation: The business case has the complete cost-benefit analysis for the project. It can provide the project manager with all the initial information used to justify the project. PMBOK 6th Edition, Page 125.

Framework.Question: The iterative process of increasing the level of detail in a project management plan as greater amounts of information and more accurate estimates become available is called:-
Framework.Explanation: Progressive Elaboration. The iterative process of increasing the level of detail in a project management plan as greater amounts of information and more accurate estimates become available. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 715

Framework.Question: Frank has assigned multiple team leads for different tasks. He is managing the release of a new drug in the market. His role is that of a:
Framework.Choice 1: A) Functional Manager, because he has good functional knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Project Manager, because he is creating a unique product within specific time schedules.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Operations Manager, because he has to do several repetitive tasks.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Program Manager, because he has to manage several projects to do his job effectively. "
Framework.Explanation: Table 2-1. Influences of Organizational Structures on Projects PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 47

Framework.Question: Which of the following is considered a review at the end of a phase in which a decision is made to continue to the next phase, to continue with modification, or to end a project or program?
Framework.Explanation: Phase Gate. A review at the end of a phase in which a decision is made to continue to the next phase, to continue with modification, or to end a project or program. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 713

Framework.Question: Ben is the CEO of an infrastructure company. Currently, the company has acquired another software development company. In a steering committee meeting, Ben asks his senior leadership team to plan and initiate the activities related to merging of two organizations. Merging two organizations is an example for:
Framework.Explanation: Merging of two organizations is an example for Project because project is a temporary endeavor and has a start and end date. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 5

Framework.Question: A CEO of a solar panels assembling company involves his senior leadership team to prepare a business case for authorizing a project to establish guidelines for handling dangerous materials. This business case is originated as a result of:-
Framework.Explanation: Establishment of proper guidelines periodically for handling dangerous materials is a mandatory legal need which every manufacturer needs to follow. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 78

Framework.Question: You are working on a small internal project. The primary purpose of the project is to introduce a new product for the sales and marketing team which can help them manage their portfolio. Which one of the following statements best defines the difference between a program and portfolios in regard to scope?
Framework.Choice 1: A) Programs do not have scopes because they are made up of projects. Portfolios have an organizational scope.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Programs have larger scopes than projects. Portfolios have an organizational scope.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Programs have larger scopes than projects. Portfolios don’t have scopes because they are a financial investment.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Programs and portfolios can share the same scope because a portfolio may have two or more programs.
Framework.Explanation: Table 1-2. Comparative Overview of Portfolios, Programs, and Projects PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 13

Framework.Question: Which of the following is NOT considered a type of organizational structure?
Framework.Explanation: There is nothing called Matrix-Hybrid.

Framework.Question: All the following are external Enterprise Environmental Factors (EEFs) except:
Framework.Explanation: EEFs vary widely in type or nature. These factors need to be considered if the project is to be effective. EEFs include but are not limited to the factors described in Sections 2.2.1 and 2.2.2. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 38, 39.

Framework.Question: You are managing an infrastructure project. The completion date for a critical milestone is approaching, but a shared team is unable to commit to achieving it on schedule. What should you do to meet the milestone date?
Framework.Choice 1: A) Ask the client to change the milestone date.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Remind the shared team about the importance of the milestone.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Approach the shared team's functional manager to request additional support.
Framework.Explanation: The project manager is working in a matrix or functional organization so, the project manager should approach the shared team's functional manager to request additional support. Option (Remind the shared team about the milestone's importance) is not a good action because they are already unable to commit to achieving it on schedule. Option (Request the additional resources) is not correct because the project manager has no authority and should ask the functional manager for support. Option (Ask the client to change the milestone date) is not a good practice in such situation.

Framework.Question: The customer asks the project manager to share the latest work performance report in WhatsApp; as he is out for vacation. What should the project manager do next?
Framework.Choice 1: A) Review organization process assets to know policies and procedures.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Discuss the issue with team and senior management.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Immediately share the report to the customer.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Politely refuse to share the report in WhatsApp; as it is unethical.
Framework.Explanation: Here in this scenario, the project manager should first review the organization process assets (OPA) to know the corporate policies and procedures for social media, ethics, and security. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 383

Framework.Question: Roy works as a project manager for a construction company. He has recently joined the organization and has been given a very large and complex project. Where can Roy expect software, templates, and standardized policies?
Framework.Explanation: Processes, policies, and procedures are usually established by the project management office (PMO) or another function outside of the project. These can be updated only by following the appropriate organizational policies associated with updating processes, policies, or procedures. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 40

Framework.Question: Antonio is a project manager who is working with the project team to prepare project management plan. The project requires at least 5 resources who have specialized knowledge on a particular niche technology. What needs to be reviewed to find out whether such resources are available internally?
Framework.Explanation: Resource availability and employee capability are examples of internal EEF. Project team should review internal EEF to get the information in relation to resource and knowledge available internally within the organization. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 38

Framework.Question: One of the most important tools and techniques a project manager should have while managing a team is the interpersonal and team skills such as:
Framework.Explanation: Figure 9-12. Manage Team: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 345.

Framework.Question: Mindy is a senior project manager who is presently performing Define Scope, Define Activities, Develop Schedule, and Determine Budget processes. These responsibilities are performed as part of:
Framework.Explanation: Planning Process Group. Those processes required to establish the scope of the project, refine the objectives, and define the course of action required to attain the objectives that the project was undertaken to achieve. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 23

Framework.Question: The project of building a new sports stadium is running smoothly with a team of generalizing specialists. The control of the product planning and delivery has been delegated to the project team. The project manager is trying to build a collaborative decision-making environment while ensuring that the team has the ability to respond to changes. What development approach is being followed in this project?
Framework.Explanation: Agile projects run in iterative and incremental fashion with team responsible for planning and delivery. The question suggests that the project is being run using Agile approach where team is controlling planning and execution. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 74

Framework.Question: You are managing a project which has developers, quality specialists and HR professionals. You have maximum authority. To which organizational structure does your company belong?
Framework.Explanation: Table 2-1. Organizational Structure and its influences on projects, Information Technology Project Management, page 50

Framework.Question: Several experts have gathered to build an implementation strategy for making a data protection software for a new IT organization. What can guide them with information in relation to legal and regulatory requirements and constraints to be taken care while developing a document that will formally authorize the existence of the project?
Framework.Choice 3: C) Historical Information in relation to Data Protection
Framework.Explanation: In this case, EEF needs to be reviewed to take necessary guidance on legal and regulatory requirements which can impact the upcoming project in future. Further, EEF is an input for develop project charter process, and currently develop project charter process is getting performed. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 78

Framework.Question: Marcos is a leader of a contracting company. He is heading a department that standardizes project related governance processes and acts as liaison between the balanced scorecard and the program, projects, portfolios of the organization. He has high degree of authority, and the project managers of all business critical projects are reporting to him. What kind of organization structure type Marcos is leading?
Framework.Choice 1: A) Marcos is acting as the COO of the contracting company.
Framework.Choice 2: B) Marcos is heading a strong matrix organization.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Marcos is heading a PMO of type Controlling.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Marcos is heading a PMO of type Directive.
Framework.Explanation: The question states that Marcos is leading project management office of the contracting company. There are three types of PMO:- Supportive, Directive, and Controlling. According to the situation stated in the question, Marcos is heading PMO of type Directive. Directive PMOs control and manage the project, and project managers directly report to the PMO. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 48

Framework.Question: You have recently joined a trading company as a project manager. The senior management has involved you in the preparation of the project charter for their car tyres manufacturing project. What should you do to know the marketplace conditions and current industry standards?
Framework.Choice 2: B) Review the enterprise environmental factors (EEF) internal to the organization.
Framework.Choice 3: C) Review the enterprise environmental factors (EEF) external to the organization.
Framework.Choice 4: D) Examine the historical information and lessons learned repository.
Framework.Explanation: The question states that the recently joined project manager has been involved in the preparation of the project charter of the company’s upcoming internal project. Here, all options are inputs to the develop project charter process, but the question asked what needs to be reviewed to know the market conditions and industry standards, which are examples of external enterprise environmental factors, because they are outside the control of the project team. Therefore, among all options provided, C is the best answer. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 39, 78

Framework.Question: A collection of related projects that are managed in a coordinated way to obtain benefits is called a:
Framework.Explanation: The PMBOK Guide defines a Program as: "a group of related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually".

Framework.Question: You are working for an organization which heavily follows the PMI processes and methodologies. Your colleagues often talk about the enterprise environmental factors. Which of the following statements about Enterprise Environmental Factors is NOT true?
Framework.Choice 1: A) Neither promote nor hold back the project management processes.
Framework.Choice 2: B) May restrict the project management processes.
Framework.Choice 3: C) May promote the project management processes.
Framework.Choice 4: D) May either promote or hold back the project management processes.
Framework.Explanation: Enterprise environmental factors (EEFs) refer to conditions, not under the control of the project team, that influence, constrain, or direct the project. These conditions can be internal and/or external to the organization. EEFs are considered as inputs to many project management processes, specifically for most planning processes. These factors may enhance or constrain project management options. In addition, these factors may have a positive or negative influence on the outcome. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 38

Initiation.Question: What type of processes are best described as incremental, interactive, and adaptive?
Initiation.Explanation: Empirical processes are interactive, incremental, change often, adapt, and pass through the reviews; they are change-driven.

Initiation.Question: When will the team demonstrate the increment they have built during a sprint?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) In the next modeling session
Initiation.Choice 2: B) During the next sprint review
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Before the start of the next sprint
Initiation.Choice 4: D) At the next sprint retrospective
Initiation.Explanation: During the sprint review, the team demonstrates what they have built in the previous sprint to the product owner and he inspects the works and determines whether it is "done" or requires any changes.

Initiation.Question: Who is responsible for selecting the number of items for the sprint from the product backlog?
Initiation.Explanation: The number of items selected from the Product Backlog for the Sprint is up to the development team based on the estimated team velocity.

Initiation.Question: A project manager has taken over a project which is under closure. The customer has accepted the deliverable, and the project manager is trying to determine who should sign off on the project. What should the project manager do?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Refer to the project charter.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Ask the customer to sign.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) The project manager can sign himself.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Consult with the project sponsor.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project approval requirements (i.e., what constitutes project success, who decides the project is successful, and who signs off on the project).

Initiation.Question: Alex has been asked to coach a team that is just switching to agile. The team asks him whether it is true that the agile team does not use plans. Alex explains that agile teams prepare plans, but sticking to those plans is less important than:
Initiation.Explanation: The Agile Manifesto states that agile teams focus on responding to change over following a plan.

Initiation.Question: The upper management in your company have decided to launch a new project and they choose you to lead the project. You believe that managing high-level requirements would ensure project success. What document should you refer to?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: High-level requirements PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81.

Initiation.Question: Who creates the product vision in an Agile project?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner is the one who creates the product vision.

Initiation.Question: When working with a scrum team, who is primarily responsible for ensuring that the value is delivered by the project?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner has the primary responsibility for ensuring that value is delivered by a scrum project. They do this by managing the product backlog and making sure that the team has a correct understanding of the project vision, project goals, and product requirements.

Initiation.Question: Andy's scrum team has just finished holding a daily scrum meeting. What part of the scrum process is her team currently in?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) They are in the middle of an itertion.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) They are conducting a sprint.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) They are about to hold a sprint review.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) They have finished the sprint planning effort.
Initiation.Explanation: Daily scrum meetings are held during the sprints. Scrum teams uses the term "sprint" instead of the term "iteration".

Initiation.Question: Which of the following documents provides the project manager the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81

Initiation.Question: An agile team used a simple change management process where the product owner could reprioritize user stories based on the customer feedback. New user stories would need to be the same relative size because those being replaced in order to maintain a fixed budget and schedule. The final product included the highest value customer features and the project was completed on schedule and budget. What Agile Manifesto value did the team emphasize to ensure project success?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Responding to change over following a plan
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Working software over comprehensive documentation
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Initiation.Explanation: The scenario emphasized the change management process, flexibility, welcoming, and accomodating changes while including the features that represented the highest value. While the scenario does not explicitly mention the original plan that was not followed.

Initiation.Question: What does the Agile Manifesto value over processes and tools?
Initiation.Explanation: The Agile Manifesto values individuals and interactions over processes and tools.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following Scrum Events focuses on the “product”?
Initiation.Explanation: The Sprint Review Meeting is a product-centric meeting held at the end of each sprint where the development team demonstrates the functionality they have completed during the sprint, asks for feedback, and seeks the acceptance of this functionality by the Product Owner.

Initiation.Question: You have just replaced a fellow project manager. After reviewing the project documents, you couldn’t find any project charter, and by speaking with the sponsor you were told that your company executes many projects without using project charters. As a project manager, you should:
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Conduct a meeting with the sponsor to discuss the urge of having a project charter.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Establish a project charter and conduct a meeting with your team to explain everyone’s duties and responsibilities and to clarify the project’s key deliverables.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Establish a draft of the project charter and raise to your manager.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Conduct a kick-off meeting and announce project start.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter establishes a partnership between the performing and requesting organizations. In the case of external projects, a formal contract is typically the preferred way to establish an agreement. A project charter may still be used to establish internal agreements within an organization to ensure proper delivery under the contract. The approved project charter formally initiates the project.

Initiation.Question: William is an agile practitioner and he is attending a scrum meeting where the team is demonstrating some individual product components to the customer via Skype in anticipation of a major feature release coming up in two weeks. What scrum meeting is the team currently attending?
Initiation.Explanation: The sprint review meeting is a product-oriented meeting held at the sprint to demonstrate product components completed within that iteration to the product owner, customer, and other interested stakeholders.

Initiation.Question: The project charter is the document that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. Who usually issues the project charter?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81

Initiation.Question: Ted is an agile practitioner and he was explaining the differences and similaritites between agile and traditional project management approaches to a senior manager. After this conversation, Ted realized that he misstated one important point which is:
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Both traditional and agile methods allow for changes throughout the project.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Both agile and traditional methods are value-driven.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Agile methods are iterative and non-incremental.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Too much planning on agile projects introduces risk.
Initiation.Explanation: Agile methods are iterative and incremental. Agile delivers increments to focus on the important features first and to deliver these features to the customer sooner.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following is considered an input to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: Figure 4-6. Direct and Manage Project Work: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 90.

Initiation.Question: What does NOT belong to the agile manifesto's main pillars?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Working software over comprehensive documentation
Initiation.Explanation: In Agile manifesto people and their interactions are considered more valuable when compared to processes. PMI Agile Practice guide page, 08

Initiation.Question: There are five scrum ceremonies. Which one of the following is not a scrum ceremony?
Initiation.Explanation: The five scrum ceremonies are: Product backlog refinement, Sprint planning meetings, Daily scrum, Sprint reviews, Sprint retrospective.

Initiation.Question: Assume that you are a project manager and you are having a phase gate meeting to decide whether to proceed with the following phase or not. Which of the following documents you are most likely to use?
Initiation.Explanation: A phase gate, is held at the end of a phase. The project’s performance and progress are compared to project and business documents including but not limited to Project charter. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 21.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following in relation to project charter is NOT true?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) The project charter establishes a partnership between performing and requesting organizations.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) The project charter formally authorizes the existence of a project.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) The project charter is considered to be a contract.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) The project charter can contain the key stakeholder list.
Initiation.Explanation: A Project Charter cannot be considered as a contract because there is no consideration or any money promised or exchanged in its creation.

Initiation.Question: During the middle of a tower construction project that is using Agile-scrum methodology, the scrum master leaves the company. This was documented as a risk during the initiation phase of the project. What corrective action needs to be taken care in the situation mentioned above?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Examine the assumption log and take appropriate action.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Ask the product owner to play dual role.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Ask the senior most team member to play the role of scrum master.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Review the project charter and work with the functional manager to resolve the issue.
Initiation.Explanation: Project Charter also captures the overall project risks at high level. Since the question states that the exit of the Scrum Master has already been documented as risk during Initiation so, it’s obvious that the project manager or any related responsible authority should consult the project charter, risk response plan developed to handle the stated risk, and then work with the functional manager to execute necessary steps involved in resolving the issue. Options A and B are not correct; as role changes or implementation of dual roles are not examples of best practices. Option C is also ruled out; as it will not provide any solution. Among all options, option D is the best choice.

Initiation.Question: Recently, you have been appointed to manage an ongoing software development project that has an agile development approach and you discovered that your team has been stuck in the current phase of the project for three months with minimal progress. You want to review the project exit criteria in order to be able to take an informed decision whether to cancel the project or not. What should you do?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Perform the control quality process.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Hold a meeting with key stakeholders to understand the project's issues.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project exit criteria (i.e., what are the conditions to be met in order to close or to cancel the project or phase).

Initiation.Question: Which of the following cannot be an input to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: Figure 4-2. Develop Project Charter: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 75

Initiation.Question: An Agile team is demonstrating a recently developed product. Who determines when a product is complete?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner accepts the completed product increment in the iteration review meeting after reviewing the acceptance criteria and verifying the functionality.

Initiation.Question: Jack is a product owner. For the upcoming sprint, he created and groomed the backlog to include software features only. Then, he set up a product review meeting. What is the main purpose of this meeting?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) To demonstrate product to the customer in order to obtain feedback.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) To capture and record requirements.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) To provide opportunity for end-users to test and verify that the system is working as designed.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) To demonstrate the team progress to the project stakeholders.
Initiation.Explanation: Obtaining feedback during product review is the best way of determining if team's effort adds value and is to the customer's satisfaction.

Initiation.Question: You have joined an ongoing project as a project manager and you want to check the project performance by reviewing the success criteria and measurable project objectives in order to plan for any corrective actions. What document should assist you to do so?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project purpose; Measurable project objectives and related success criteria, and High-level requirements.

Initiation.Question: Lessons learned from previous projects and historical information are included in which of the following inputs to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: OPAs include any artifact, practice, or knowledge from any or all of the performing organizations involved in the project that can be used to execute or govern the project. The OPAs also include the organization’s lessons learned from previous projects and historical information.

Initiation.Question: You have been assigned as a project manager for an ongoing project and you want to know the limits of your role, authority, and responsibility. What document should you review?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as:Assigned project manager, responsibility, and authority level.

Initiation.Question: What type of processes are best described as incremental, interactive, and adaptive?
Initiation.Explanation: Empirical processes are interactive, incremental, change often, adapt, and pass through the reviews; they are change-driven.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following Scrum Events focuses on the “product”?
Initiation.Explanation: The Sprint Review Meeting is a product-centric meeting held at the end of each sprint where the development team demonstrates the functionality they have completed during the sprint, asks for feedback, and seeks the acceptance of this functionality by the Product Owner.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following cannot be an input to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: Figure 4-2. Develop Project Charter: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 75

Initiation.Question: Which of the following in relation to project charter is NOT true?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) The project charter establishes a partnership between performing and requesting organizations.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) The project charter formally authorizes the existence of a project.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) The project charter is considered to be a contract.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) The project charter can contain the key stakeholder list.
Initiation.Explanation: A Project Charter cannot be considered as a contract because there is no consideration or any money promised or exchanged in its creation.

Initiation.Question: What does NOT belong to the agile manifesto's main pillars?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Working software over comprehensive documentation
Initiation.Explanation: In Agile manifesto people and their interactions are considered more valuable when compared to processes. PMI Agile Practice guide page, 08

Initiation.Question: Ted is an agile practitioner and he was explaining the differences and similaritites between agile and traditional project management approaches to a senior manager. After this conversation, Ted realized that he misstated one important point which is:
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Both traditional and agile methods allow for changes throughout the project.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Both agile and traditional methods are value-driven.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Agile methods are iterative and non-incremental.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Too much planning on agile projects introduces risk.
Initiation.Explanation: Agile methods are iterative and incremental. Agile delivers increments to focus on the important features first and to deliver these features to the customer sooner.

Initiation.Question: Andy's scrum team has just finished holding a daily scrum meeting. What part of the scrum process is her team currently in?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) They are in the middle of an itertion.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) They are conducting a sprint.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) They are about to hold a sprint review.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) They have finished the sprint planning effort.
Initiation.Explanation: Daily scrum meetings are held during the sprints. Scrum teams uses the term "sprint" instead of the term "iteration".

Initiation.Question: When will the team demonstrate the increment they have built during a sprint?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) In the next modeling session
Initiation.Choice 2: B) During the next sprint review
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Before the start of the next sprint
Initiation.Choice 4: D) At the next sprint retrospective
Initiation.Explanation: During the sprint review, the team demonstrates what they have built in the previous sprint to the product owner and he inspects the works and determines whether it is "done" or requires any changes.

Initiation.Question: Recently, you have been appointed to manage an ongoing software development project that has an agile development approach and you discovered that your team has been stuck in the current phase of the project for three months with minimal progress. You want to review the project exit criteria in order to be able to take an informed decision whether to cancel the project or not. What should you do?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Perform the control quality process.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Hold a meeting with key stakeholders to understand the project's issues.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project exit criteria (i.e., what are the conditions to be met in order to close or to cancel the project or phase).

Initiation.Question: An agile team used a simple change management process where the product owner could reprioritize user stories based on the customer feedback. New user stories would need to be the same relative size because those being replaced in order to maintain a fixed budget and schedule. The final product included the highest value customer features and the project was completed on schedule and budget. What Agile Manifesto value did the team emphasize to ensure project success?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Responding to change over following a plan
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Working software over comprehensive documentation
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Initiation.Explanation: The scenario emphasized the change management process, flexibility, welcoming, and accomodating changes while including the features that represented the highest value. While the scenario does not explicitly mention the original plan that was not followed.

Initiation.Question: Who is responsible for selecting the number of items for the sprint from the product backlog?
Initiation.Explanation: The number of items selected from the Product Backlog for the Sprint is up to the development team based on the estimated team velocity.

Initiation.Question: Alex has been asked to coach a team that is just switching to agile. The team asks him whether it is true that the agile team does not use plans. Alex explains that agile teams prepare plans, but sticking to those plans is less important than:
Initiation.Explanation: The Agile Manifesto states that agile teams focus on responding to change over following a plan.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following documents provides the project manager the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81

Initiation.Question: What does the Agile Manifesto value over processes and tools?
Initiation.Explanation: The Agile Manifesto values individuals and interactions over processes and tools.

Initiation.Question: An Agile team is demonstrating a recently developed product. Who determines when a product is complete?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner accepts the completed product increment in the iteration review meeting after reviewing the acceptance criteria and verifying the functionality.

Initiation.Question: Lessons learned from previous projects and historical information are included in which of the following inputs to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: OPAs include any artifact, practice, or knowledge from any or all of the performing organizations involved in the project that can be used to execute or govern the project. The OPAs also include the organization’s lessons learned from previous projects and historical information.

Initiation.Question: Jack is a product owner. For the upcoming sprint, he created and groomed the backlog to include software features only. Then, he set up a product review meeting. What is the main purpose of this meeting?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) To demonstrate product to the customer in order to obtain feedback.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) To capture and record requirements.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) To provide opportunity for end-users to test and verify that the system is working as designed.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) To demonstrate the team progress to the project stakeholders.
Initiation.Explanation: Obtaining feedback during product review is the best way of determining if team's effort adds value and is to the customer's satisfaction.

Initiation.Question: Which of the following is considered an input to the Develop Project Charter process?
Initiation.Explanation: Figure 4-6. Direct and Manage Project Work: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 90.

Initiation.Question: The upper management in your company have decided to launch a new project and they choose you to lead the project. You believe that managing high-level requirements would ensure project success. What document should you refer to?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: High-level requirements PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81.

Initiation.Question: A project manager has taken over a project which is under closure. The customer has accepted the deliverable, and the project manager is trying to determine who should sign off on the project. What should the project manager do?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Refer to the project charter.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Ask the customer to sign.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) The project manager can sign himself.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Consult with the project sponsor.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project approval requirements (i.e., what constitutes project success, who decides the project is successful, and who signs off on the project).

Initiation.Question: When working with a scrum team, who is primarily responsible for ensuring that the value is delivered by the project?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner has the primary responsibility for ensuring that value is delivered by a scrum project. They do this by managing the product backlog and making sure that the team has a correct understanding of the project vision, project goals, and product requirements.

Initiation.Question: You have been assigned as a project manager for an ongoing project and you want to know the limits of your role, authority, and responsibility. What document should you review?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as:Assigned project manager, responsibility, and authority level.

Initiation.Question: During the middle of a tower construction project that is using Agile-scrum methodology, the scrum master leaves the company. This was documented as a risk during the initiation phase of the project. What corrective action needs to be taken care in the situation mentioned above?
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Examine the assumption log and take appropriate action.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Ask the product owner to play dual role.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Ask the senior most team member to play the role of scrum master.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Review the project charter and work with the functional manager to resolve the issue.
Initiation.Explanation: Project Charter also captures the overall project risks at high level. Since the question states that the exit of the Scrum Master has already been documented as risk during Initiation so, it’s obvious that the project manager or any related responsible authority should consult the project charter, risk response plan developed to handle the stated risk, and then work with the functional manager to execute necessary steps involved in resolving the issue. Options A and B are not correct; as role changes or implementation of dual roles are not examples of best practices. Option C is also ruled out; as it will not provide any solution. Among all options, option D is the best choice.

Initiation.Question: There are five scrum ceremonies. Which one of the following is not a scrum ceremony?
Initiation.Explanation: The five scrum ceremonies are: Product backlog refinement, Sprint planning meetings, Daily scrum, Sprint reviews, Sprint retrospective.

Initiation.Question: Assume that you are a project manager and you are having a phase gate meeting to decide whether to proceed with the following phase or not. Which of the following documents you are most likely to use?
Initiation.Explanation: A phase gate, is held at the end of a phase. The project’s performance and progress are compared to project and business documents including but not limited to Project charter. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 21.

Initiation.Question: William is an agile practitioner and he is attending a scrum meeting where the team is demonstrating some individual product components to the customer via Skype in anticipation of a major feature release coming up in two weeks. What scrum meeting is the team currently attending?
Initiation.Explanation: The sprint review meeting is a product-oriented meeting held at the sprint to demonstrate product components completed within that iteration to the product owner, customer, and other interested stakeholders.

Initiation.Question: You have joined an ongoing project as a project manager and you want to check the project performance by reviewing the success criteria and measurable project objectives in order to plan for any corrective actions. What document should assist you to do so?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project. It documents the high-level information on the project and on the product, service, or result the project is intended to satisfy, such as: Project purpose; Measurable project objectives and related success criteria, and High-level requirements.

Initiation.Question: Who creates the product vision in an Agile project?
Initiation.Explanation: The product owner is the one who creates the product vision.

Initiation.Question: The project charter is the document that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. Who usually issues the project charter?
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter is the document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 81

Initiation.Question: You have just replaced a fellow project manager. After reviewing the project documents, you couldn’t find any project charter, and by speaking with the sponsor you were told that your company executes many projects without using project charters. As a project manager, you should:
Initiation.Choice 1: A) Conduct a meeting with the sponsor to discuss the urge of having a project charter.
Initiation.Choice 2: B) Establish a project charter and conduct a meeting with your team to explain everyone’s duties and responsibilities and to clarify the project’s key deliverables.
Initiation.Choice 3: C) Establish a draft of the project charter and raise to your manager.
Initiation.Choice 4: D) Conduct a kick-off meeting and announce project start.
Initiation.Explanation: The project charter establishes a partnership between the performing and requesting organizations. In the case of external projects, a formal contract is typically the preferred way to establish an agreement. A project charter may still be used to establish internal agreements within an organization to ensure proper delivery under the contract. The approved project charter formally initiates the project.

Stakeholders.Question: Assume that you are a project manager for a project in its initiating phase. After identifying the probable stakeholders, you want to categorize these stakeholders in order to gain support for the project. What should you do?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Start the Collect Requirements process.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Inform stakeholders of the approved project charter.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Domain I initiating - Task 3) Perform stakeholder analysis using appropriate tools and techniques in order to align expectations and gain support for the project. PMI PMP Examination Content Outline – June 2015

Stakeholders.Question: The development team of our software development project is conducting a review meeting. In this meeting, the team is also passing of acceptance test cases which are an example of:
Stakeholders.Explanation: Definition of Done (DoD). A team’s checklist of all the criteria required to be met so that a deliverable can be considered ready for customer use.

Stakeholders.Question: Ricky is a project manager of a university extension project. It came to his knowledge that a very powerful stakeholder, who was not identified in his stakeholder list, is not satisfied with his project performance. This stakeholder asked for some updates to be done in the project. What should Ricky do FIRST?
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Issue a change request to the CCB.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Analyze the impact of the request on the project.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Since the stakeholder was not identified in the stakeholder list, then the project manager should first update him in the stakeholder register.

Stakeholders.Question: As you are planning for stakeholder engagement management, you want to classify the various project stakeholders according to their participation level in the project whether they are unaware, resistant, neutral or supportive in order to analyze the factors behind their attitude and boost them if they are supportive or make necessary changes if they were not. What tool/technique should you use?
Stakeholders.Explanation: A stakeholder engagement assessment matrix supports comparison between the current engagement levels of stakeholders and the desired engagement levels required for successful project delivery. The engagement level of stakeholders can be classified as follows: Unaware. Unaware of the project and potential impacts. Resistant. Aware of the project and potential impacts but resistant to any changes that may occur as a result of the work or outcomes of the project. These stakeholders will be unsupportive of the work or outcomes of the project. Neutral. Aware of the project, but neither supportive nor unsupportive. Supportive. Aware of the project and potential impacts and supportive of the work and its outcomes. Leading. Aware of the project and potential impacts and actively engaged in ensuring that the project is a success. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 521

Stakeholders.Question: The main purpose of conducting the kick-off meeting is to:
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Inform and engage stakeholders and gain commitment.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Ensure that work is performed in accordance with required quality standards.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Obtain approval to proceed with project execution.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Domain II - Planning Task 12) Conduct kick-off meeting, communicating the start of the project, key milestones, and other relevant information in order to inform and engage stakeholders and gain commitment. PMI PMP Examination Content Outline – June 2015

Stakeholders.Question: When a new influential stakeholder joins the organization and will be responsible for a few aspects of the project, what should the project manager do FIRST to engage this stakeholder effectively?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Revise the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Update the RACI chart with the responsibilities of the new stakeholder.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Submit a change request to update the stakeholder engagement plan.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Schedule a meeting with the new project stakeholder.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Manage Stakeholder Engagement process is the process of communicating and working with stakeholders to meet their needs and expectations, address issues, and foster the appropriate stakeholder involvement. In order to effectively manage the new stakeholder's level of engagement, the project manager must understand, among other things, the stakeholder's requirements and expectations. Meeting with the stakeholder provides an opportunity for the project manager to establish a relationship and gather the necessary information from the stakeholder to engage him effectively. Therefore, of the available options, the first thing for the project manager to do is meeting with the stakeholder to learn the stakeholder's requirements and expectations for the project. The incorrect answer choices represent actions that may not be necessary, or the project manager does not have enough information to perform at this point.

Stakeholders.Question: You got information that a stakeholder who has great power and not identified in your stakeholder list is not happy with your project performance. He asked for some updates to be made in the project. What is the first action you should do?
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Issue a change request to CCB.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Analyze the impact of the request on the project.
Stakeholders.Explanation: As STAKEHOLDER NOT IDENTIFIED is mentioned, the first step is that you should update him in the stakeholder register.

Stakeholders.Question: You are a project manager who is updating the stakeholder register to include 5 specialists who have just joined your project on a temporary basis to implement a business critical task that involves pure risk. How will the newly appointed specialists be classified in the stakeholder register based on their direction of influence in the project?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) 5 Specialists will be marked as Sideward in the stakeholder register.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) 5 Specialists will be marked as Downward in the stakeholder register.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) 5 Specialists will be marked as Influential in the power/interest grid.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) 5 Specialists will be marked as Outward in the stakeholder register.
Stakeholders.Explanation: The question implies that the 5 specialists are hired on a temporary basis to complete an important project work. It suggests that their direction of influence in the project is Downward; as they can influence the project with their specialized knowledge in a temporary capacity. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 513

Stakeholders.Question: Persona is important to the success of a product because they drive design decisions by taking common user needs and bringing them to the forefront of planning before the design has actually started. What is a persona?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Any stakeholder who can provide system requirements
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) A business analyst or a SME
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Imaginary representation of a user role
Stakeholders.Explanation: A persona is either the public image of one's personality, or the social role that one adopts, or a fictional character.

Stakeholders.Question: You are in charge of building a shopping portal. You are fairly confident; as you have a team experienced in doing such work. As per the agreement, at the end of the first month, you organize a demonstration of the application and you invite the sponsor and the key stakeholders. Later, the sponsor informs you that he is not very happy with the progress indicating that one of the clients who would be using this application is not satisfied; as his needs are not being met. Satisfying this client’s needs would mean some radical changes with an impact on both cost and schedule. What could be the root cause of this issue?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) The stakeholder is making unrealistic demands.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) The scope statement was ambiguous.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Deliverables were not as per requirement.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) All the stakeholders were not identified.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Identify Stakeholders is the process of identifying project stakeholders regularly and analyzing and documenting relevant information regarding their interests, involvement, interdependencies, influence, and potential impact on project success. The key benefit of this process is that it enables the project team to identify the appropriate focus for engagement of each stakeholder or group of stakeholders. This process is performed periodically throughout the project as needed. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 507

Stakeholders.Question: How can your agile team prevent a gap between what the customer wants and what you build for them?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Make sure that the project charter is as detailed as possible.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Invite the customer to the release retrospectives.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Progressively elaborate the product demonstrations.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Negotiate how the customer will define completion.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Negotiating how the customer will define completion is another way of creating a shared "definition of done".

Stakeholders.Question: Steve is managing a construction project. A product development manager, who is unsure of initial prototype’s requirements, is upset to learn that it should be completed in 3 months. What should the Steve have done to prevent this?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Included the product development manager in the communications management plan.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Ensured that the right resources were assigned to the project.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Obtained the required resources from the procurement manager.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Obtained stakeholders' agreement on the project’s schedule and deliverables.
Stakeholders.Explanation: As long as the project manager is unsure if the prototype is matching or not, he should first obtain the stakeholders’ agreement.

Stakeholders.Question: Recently, you have been selected by your organization to manage a project from scratch, and you know that managing stakeholder's engagement is crucial for the success of the project. As you start identifying stakeholders, you want to classify them according to their influence on the work of the project as well as their position. Which stakeholders’ classification method should you use?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Directions of influence classifies stakeholders according to their influence on the work of the project or the project team itself. Stakeholders can be classified in the following ways: Upward (senior management of the performing organization or customer organization, sponsor, and steering committee), Downward (the team or specialists contributing knowledge or skills in a temporary capacity), Outward (stakeholder groups and their representatives outside the project team, such as suppliers, government departments, the public, end-users, and regulators), or Sideward (the peers of the project manager, such as other project managers or middle managers who are in competition for scarce project resources or who collaborate with the project manager in sharing resources or information). PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 513

Stakeholders.Question: A project that involved a multiple number of vendors is about to close. There have been significant changes in contractors and suppliers during the life cycle of the project to meet the growing project needs. Where these changes should be reflected?
Stakeholders.Explanation: As the project work progresses through the execution phase, the contractors and suppliers may change. These changes are reflected in the stakeholder register. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 501

Stakeholders.Question: Which of the following is considered a data representation technique used after identifying project stakeholders that categorizes stakeholder according to their level of authority and level of concern about the project’s outcomes?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Power/interest grid, power/influence grid, or impact/influence grid. Each of these techniques supports a grouping of stakeholders according to their level of authority (power), level of concern about the project’s outcomes (interest), ability to influence the outcomes of the project (influence), or ability to cause changes to the project’s planning or execution. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 512

Stakeholders.Question: What is NOT true regarding identify stakeholder process?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Post first iteration of stakeholder engagement process, business document acts as sources of information about project's stakeholders.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Change log and requirement documentation are valid inputs for identify stakeholder process.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Communication management plan may act as a valid input for identify stakeholder process only after the first iteration of the identify stakeholder process.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Stakeholder identification process can periodically happen throughout the project on need basis.
Stakeholders.Explanation: In the first iteration of the Identify Stakeholders process, the business case and the benefits management plan are sources of information about the project’s stakeholders. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 509

Stakeholders.Question: You are a project manager of a hotel renovation project. After reviewing your vendors' performance, you discovered that one vendor is delivering low quality products and should be replaced by his competitor. What document should you update?
Stakeholders.Explanation: As the work progresses through the execution phase, the contractors and suppliers may change. These changes should be reflected in the stakeholder register. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 501.

Stakeholders.Question: A project manager joins a project during its initial planning phase. The project involves various local government institutions. While interviewing the project sponsor, the project manager learns of the importance of keeping the security officers of two of these institutions satisfied; since project development will be affected without their involvement. What should the project manager use to record and monitor this information?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Power/interest grid supports a grouping of stakeholders according to their level of authority (power), level of concern about the project's outcomes (interest).

Stakeholders.Question: As part of stakeholder management and understanding, the team may undertake customer persona modeling. Which of the following would a persona NOT represent in this context?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Personas do represent real, stereotyped, composite, and fictional people. They are archetypal (exemplary) descriptions, grounded in reality, goal-oriented, specific, and relevant to generate focus. Personas are not a replacement for requirements on a project, however.

Stakeholders.Question: Robert is managing an airport construction project. He is currently assessing stakeholder aspects like their interests, rights, ownership, knowledge, and contributions. What will be his preference of technique to work this out?
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Stakeholder Mapping using Salience Model
Stakeholders.Explanation: Stakeholder analysis results in a list of stakeholders and relevant information such as their positions in the organization, roles on the project, “stakes”, expectations, attitudes (their levels of support for the project), and their interest in information about the project. Stakeholders’ stakes can include but are not limited to a combination of interest, rights, contribution and ownership.

Stakeholders.Question: To consolidate an organization's development through the engagement of stakeholders, which of the following is the necessary skill needed?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Ensure all stakeholders are engaged appropriately by updating the stakeholder registry upon changes to the project.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Build relationships with key stakeholders with a working agreement to allow effective collaboration.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Foster group decision making and conflict resolution in order to maintain a good relationship among stakeholder.
Stakeholders.Explanation: All the above mentioned skills are necessary to enhance effective engagement of stakeholders.

Stakeholders.Question: You are the project manager of a software development project and your team has successfully completed the third milestone of the project out of five planned. And as per the project's schedule, the work to be implemented in the next milestone requires inputs form another department within your organization, but the specific employee that will be working on your project has not been selected yet. As soon as the employee get selected, the project manager should:
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Conduct a one-on-one meeting with the selected employee.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Introduce the new employee to the project team.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Perform the Identify Stakeholders process.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Identify Stakeholders is the process of identifying project stakeholders regularly and analyzing and documenting relevant information regarding their interests, involvement, interdependencies, influence, and potential impact on project success. This process frequently occurs for the first time in a project either prior to or at the same time the project charter is developed and approved. It is repeated as necessary, but should be performed at the start of each phase and when a significant change in the project or the organization occurs. Each time the identification process is repeated, the project management plan components and project documents should be consulted to identify relevant project stakeholders. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 507,508

Stakeholders.Question: A project manager wants to ensure sufficient stakeholder participation throughout a project’s life cycle. What should the project manager include in the stakeholder engagement plan?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Desired and current stakeholder engagement levels
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Feedback from stakeholders on project operations
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Change requests initiated by stakeholders
Stakeholders.Explanation: A stakeholder engagement assessment matrix supports comparison between the current engagement levels of stakeholders and the desired engagement levels required for successful project delivery. To ensure sufficient stakeholder participation throughout a project’s life cycle, the project manager should include the desired and current stakeholder engagement levels in the stakeholder engagement plan.

Stakeholders.Question: A project manager presents a project status update in a weekly meeting. A senior executive who attends this meeting for the first time, has several questions about all aspects of the project and insists on wide changes. After the meeting, the sponsor notifies the project manager that the senior executive has joined the company just a few days ago. What should the project manager do FIRST?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Ask the sponsor to increase management reserves to cover the cost of the changes requested by the executive.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Instruct the project team to implement all the changes that have been requested by the senior executive.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Look for ways to limit the senior executive's involvement since he was not involved in the initial planning.
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Update the stakeholder register and power/interest grid to account for changes in the stakeholder community.
Stakeholders.Explanation: The senior executive has been identified as a new stakeholder. The project manager should first add the senior executive to the stakeholder register and record his interest and influence on the project so that his expectations can be appropriately managed.

Stakeholders.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a complex project in which a number of key stakeholders will participate in and their input will be crucial for the success of the project and you want to make sure that their involvement is continuous throughout the project so, you want to develop approaches to guarantee stakeholders involvement based on their needs and expectations. What process should you perform?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Plan Stakeholder Engagement is the process of developing approaches to involve project stakeholders based on their needs, expectations, interests, and potential impact on the project. The key benefit is that it provides an actionable plan to interact effectively with stakeholders. This process is performed periodically throughout the project as needed. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 516

Stakeholders.Question: To stimulate stakeholders’ interest in a project, which of the following proves clearly to be the most necessary?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Understanding their basic needs by engaging stakeholders through early and continuous knowledge sharing and active listening throughout the project life cycle.
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) The definition of done must be agreed upon collectively with key stakeholders before carrying out the project works.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Presenting them the project's charter to aid their understanding of the projects' objectives.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Understanding their basic needs by engaging them through continuous knowledge sharing.

Stakeholders.Question: After the third progress meeting of the project you are managing, you received an email from a stakeholder asking about the minutes of meeting of the past two progress meeting that he did not receive, you reviewed the stakeholder register and you could not find any information about that stakeholder. As a project manager, what should you do first?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Update the communication management plan.
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Update the stakeholder management plan.
Stakeholders.Explanation: Identify Stakeholders is the process of identifying project stakeholders regularly and analyzing and documenting relevant information regarding their interests, involvement, interdependencies, influence, and potential impact on project success. This process frequently occurs for the first time in a project either prior to or at the same time the project charter is developed and approved. It is repeated as necessary, but should be performed at the start of each phase and when a significant change in the project or the organization occurs. Each time the identification process is repeated, the project management plan components and project documents should be consulted to identify relevant project stakeholders. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 507, 508.

Stakeholders.Question: After completing 70% of the project work, you received a letter from a local authority regarding some violation made by your project. You do not have enough information about the level of authority of this local authority. As a project manager, what should you do?
Stakeholders.Explanation: Identify Stakeholders is the process of identifying project stakeholders regularly and analyzing and documenting relevant information regarding their interests, involvement, interdependencies, influence, and potential impact on project success. This process frequently occurs for the first time in a project either prior to or at the same time the project charter is developed and approved. It is repeated as necessary, but should be performed at the start of each phase and when a significant change in the project or the organization occurs. Each time the identification process is repeated, the project management plan components and project documents should be consulted to identify relevant project stakeholders. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 507, 508.

Stakeholders.Question: A new project manager joins the construction project during the middle of execution. Before meeting all key stakeholders, she wants to prepare a report that shows comparison between current and desired level of engagement of stakeholders involved in the project. What should she review to fetch this necessary information?
Stakeholders.Explanation: As per the question, the project manager should consult the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix to compare stakeholders' current and desired level of engagement. Some may get confused with stakeholder engagement plan, but the stakeholder engagement plan documents how adjustments to stakeholders’ level of engagement will be achieved. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 521

Stakeholders.Question: A project is 6 months into its 9-month projected duration, and the project manager is reporting that the project is at least 3 months behind schedule because certain key stakeholders were resistant to any changes that might occur as outcomes of the project. What might have been done differently during project planning to avoid this situation?
Stakeholders.Choice 1: A) Establishment of a more robust communications management plan
Stakeholders.Choice 2: B) Creation of a comprehensive stakeholder register
Stakeholders.Choice 3: C) Better execution of the manage stakeholder engagement process
Stakeholders.Choice 4: D) Development of a stakeholder engagement assessment matrix
Stakeholders.Explanation: The scenario describes a situation where the resistance of certain key stakeholders has caused the project to run behind schedule and is asking what might have been done differently during project planning. Two of the answer choices represent activities which are not associated with the planning process group, and, as a result, those responses can be eliminated. Both of the remaining answer choices represent reasonable actions that may have led to better stakeholder engagement. The development of the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix directly addresses the issue described by the question. The stakeholder engagement assessment matrix is used as a tool during the plan stakeholder engagement process and identifies key stakeholders along with their current and desired engagement level. Classifications for stakeholder engagement may include unaware, resistant, neutral, supportive, and leading. In this scenario, certain key stakeholders were resistant to the project which caused the project to run behind schedule. A stakeholder engagement assessment matrix is the best tool for identifying resistant stakeholders with enough influence to undermine a project. In this case, identifying the current and desired engagement levels of the key stakeholders might have allowed the project manager to take action to address the undesirable engagement levels and prevent the stakeholder's resistance from negatively impact the project's performance. Therefore, of the available options, development of a stakeholder engagement assessment matrix is the best answer to the question asked.

Stakeholders.Question: Carolina is a project manager of a healthcare organization.
