Resources.Explanation: **Team building** is conducting activities that enhance the teamâ€™s social relations and build a collaborative and cooperative working environment. Team building activities can vary from a 5-minute agenda item in a status review meeting to an offsite, professionally facilitated event designed to improve interpersonal relationships. The objective of team-building activities is to help individual team members work together effectively. [9]

Resources.Question: Within your project team, you notice that emotions are at a high due to completion among the team members. People are quick to react rather than understanding each other's needs and responding appropriately. Due to this, team members are struggling to meet your project goals and results. You are also disturbed about this and speak to your sponsor who advises you to attend certain training. What training is this likely to be?
Resources.Explanation: **Emotional intelligence** is the ability to identify, assess, and manage the personal emotions of oneself and other people, as well as the collective emotions of groups of people. The team can use emotional intelligence to reduce tension and increase cooperation by identifying, assessing, and controlling the sentiments of project team members, anticipating their actions, acknowledging their concerns, and following up on their issues. [10, 11]

Resources.Question: Bruce has recently joined an organization as a project manager. He is responsible for a new project which requires resources with specific skills and competencies from various departments. As most staff are already assigned to other projects, Bruce must identify and agree on available internal human resources and hire external experts. What should Bruce use FIRST to obtain resources?
Resources.Explanation: **Negotiation**. The project manager may need to negotiate for additional physical resources, changes in physical resources, or costs associated with the resources. [11, 12]

Resources.Question: When should the project manager start to acquire and manage project resources?
Resources.Explanation: Domain III) Executing Task 1 Acquire and manage project resources by following the human resource and procurement management plans in order to meet project requirements. [12]

Resources.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a complex project with a project team of multiple nationalities and backgrounds. You want to set ground rules for acceptable behavior by the team in order to reduce conflicts and raise team morale. What should you do?
Resources.Choice 1: Conduct a weekly meeting to discuss the issue
Resources.Choice 4: Select team members of the same nationality
Resources.Explanation: The **team charter** is a document that establishes the team values, agreements, and operating guidelines for the team. The team charter establishes clear expectations regarding acceptable behavior by project team members. Early commitment to clear guidelines decreases misunderstandings and increases productivity. [13]

Resources.Question: Daniel is a project manager of an underground tunnel project. His project team consists of 10 members and the signed contract contains a training clause which states that only 3 members will be chosen for the training. What is the best way to choose the project team members who will take the training while keeping the other members with high spirit and performance without any negative impact?
Resources.Choice 1: Use your position and select the 3 members
Resources.Choice 2: Conduct a meeting with the 10 members and select 3 randomly
Resources.Choice 4: Ask the project sponsor to select 3 members
Resources.Explanation: In order to maintain the spirit and performance of the project team without any negative impact, the project manager should hold a meeting with all members and select the required No. randomly. [14, 15]

Resources.Question: The project team members are in conflict, not collaborative, and differ in opinion on the architecture. Which of the following phases of development are they in now?
Resources.Explanation: There are five stages of Team Development: Forming, **Storming**, Norming, Performing, and Adjourning. In the **Storming** phase, the team is in conflict; as they begin to address the project work, technical work, and project management approach. [15, 16]

Resources.Question: All baseline documents are approved. The project management team is engaged in reviewing the documents that guide the selection of internal and external resources which are necessary to complete the project work. Which process is currently getting performed?
Resources.Explanation: The scenario states that the **acquire resources process** is getting performed and the project management team is engaged in reviewing resource and procurement management plan so that resources can be on boarded to complete the project work. Both resource management plan and procurement management plans are inputs to the acquire resources process, which is being reviewed in this scenario. [16, 17]

Resources.Question: People are motivated when they feel they are valued in the organization and this value is demonstrated by the rewards given to them. A good strategy for project managers is to give the team recognition :
Resources.Choice 3: Throughout the life cycle of the project.
Resources.Choice 4: At the end of the project.
Resources.Explanation: People are motivated when they feel they are valued in the organization and this value is demonstrated by the rewards given to them. A good strategy for project managers is to give the team recognition **throughout the life cycle of the project** rather than waiting until the project is completed. [17, 18]

Resources.Question: Which of the following tools/techniques is essential for any project team development and its cost may be included in the project budget?
Resources.Explanation: **Training** includes all activities designed to enhance the competencies of the project team members. Training can be formal or informal. If project team members lack the necessary management or technical skills, such skills can be developed as part of the project work. Scheduled training takes place as stated in the resource management plan. Training costs could be included in the project budget or supported by the performing organization if the added skills may be useful for future projects. [19, 20]

Resources.Question: After assessing team performance, Frank realizes that the team is neither communicating well nor understanding each other's skills and limitations. Therefore, he schedules a weekend team building session that will require the team members to be off for two days immediately following the session. Where does Frank record this information?
Resources.Explanation: **Resource calendars** are used to identify working days and shifts wherein each resource is available. Because project team members are resources, updates to their schedules are entered in the resource calendar. [20, 21]

Resources.Question: The project manager and project team have worked together for many years. There is a deep sense of community and collaboration. Everyone knows their stuff and gets better with every project. Which leadership style of the project manager is MOST effective in deepening those connections?
Resources.Explanation: **Servant leadership** is a leadership approach where the project manager serves and supports the needs of the project team over everything else to maintain the high-performance level of the team and achieve the project objectives. [21, 22]

Resources.Question: Recently, you have joined an ongoing project as the quality manager of the project and you want to know to whom you should report. Which document should you review?
Resources.Explanation: The **resource management plan** may include but is not limited to: Project organization charts. A project organization chart is a graphic display of project team members and their reporting relationships. [22, 23]

Resources.Question: In your project, SPI is 0.74 and CPI 1.6. You analyzed the baseline and decided to return the schedule back on track to meet customer plan. You will:-
Resources.Choice 1: Check the option of introducing overtime in the project.
Resources.Choice 3: Check with the project team if the task can be automated and save time.
Resources.Choice 4: Check the tasks which can be removed from baseline.
Resources.Explanation: Since the CPI is over one and SPI is less than one, it means that the project is currently under budget, but is behind schedule. Therefore, among all possible options given in the above, A seems to be the best option. You need to check the option of crashing the project. **Over time is an example of crashing**. [24, 25]

Resources.Question: Robinson is managing a 6-million dollars project, where project team members are working from multiple countries. As a project manager, for handling multiculturalism, when should Robinson specially consider cultural differences ?
Resources.Choice 1: When the RACI chart gets finalized for assigning work to the available resources .
Resources.Choice 2: When he is considering recognition and rewards during team development.
Resources.Choice 3: When he is working in a co-located environment.
Resources.Choice 4: When communication strategies are built based on political environment of the organization.
Resources.Explanation: Part of the team development process involves recognizing and rewarding desirable behavior. The original plan for rewarding people is developed during the Plan Resource Management process. Rewards will be effective only if they satisfy a need that is valued by that individual. Reward decisions are made, formally or informally, during the process of managing the project team. **Cultural differences should be considered when determining recognition and rewards**. [25, 26]

Resources.Question: You are working as a project manager. A customer has been consistently late with approvals on design documentation. You have raised the subject in the past, but the practice of delayed approval has not changed. You have been documenting the delays. Which conflict resolution technique are you following?
Resources.Explanation: Documenting the delays is not an attempt to solve the problem. This demonstrates **avoidance or withdrawal** as the project manager's response to the situation. Collaborating involves attempting to solve the problem for deriving an extent of satisfaction to the parties involved in the issue. The situation described here does not indicate any such attempt. [27, 28]

Resources.Question: A team member informs the project manager that a critical task should be completed outside of the project which will pose a schedule risk to the project. What should the project manager do to eliminate the risk?
Resources.Choice 1: Report the team memberâ€™s manager to the project sponsor for noncompliance.
Resources.Choice 2: Obtain a replacement resource from another department.
Resources.Choice 3: Instruct the team memberâ€™s manager to release the team member to complete the scheduled project activity.
Resources.Choice 4: Negotiate with the team memberâ€™s manager for an alternative time to complete the other task.
Resources.Explanation: To eliminate this risk, the project manager should **negotiate with the team member's manager** to allocate an alternative period to complete the other task so that the project schedule is not affected. [28, 29]

Resources.Question: A functional manager deletes some key project resources without consulting the project manager in order to assign them operational tasks. As these resources are now focused on operational tasks rather than deliverables, the deliverables ran late. What should the project manager do first?
Resources.Choice 1: Escalate the functional managerâ€™s actions to the sponsor.
Resources.Choice 2: Negotiate time allocation to prioritize the resourcesâ€™ workload.
Resources.Choice 4: Ask to have the resources replaced immediately.
Resources.Explanation: The project management teamâ€™s ability to influence others plays an important role in **negotiating resource allocation**, as does the politics of the organizations involved. [30, 31]

Resources.Question: During a team meeting, your team members do not remain on topic and often interrupt each other. This causes the meeting to take longer than planned. As a project manager, what should you do?
Resources.Choice 3: Co-locate the team members in a place which is suitable to tea
Resources.Explanation: **Ground rules**, defined in the team charter, are established to set clear expectations regarding acceptable behavior by the project team members. Therefore, the project manager should escalate ground rule to comply to team members and remain on topic and do not interrupt each other. [31, 32]

Resources.Question: You are the project manager of a mega project and due to some variations asked by the employer, you discovered that you would need to hire a new resource for the rest of the project. Where could you find guidelines on how to hire new resources?
Resources.Explanation: Plan Resource Management is the process of defining how to estimate, acquire, manage, and use team and physical resources. The key benefit of this process is that it establishes the approach and level of management effort needed for managing project resources based on the type and complexity of the project. This process is performed once or at predefined points in the project. The **resource management plan** may include but is not limited to guidance on how to acquire team and physical resources for the project. [32, 33]

Resources.Question: During the implementation stage of a US$65 million project in a balanced matrix organization, a SME is pulled by his department manager. What should the project manager do to complete the project on time?
Resources.Choice 1: Negotiate with the department manager for replacement.
Resources.Choice 3: Refer the issue to the project management office.
Resources.Choice 4: Escalate the issue to the line manager of the department.
Resources.Explanation: Acquire Resources: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs [33, 34]

Resources.Question: A project manager wants to recruit another team member to replace an architect who resigned. What document should capture this change?
Resources.Explanation: RAMs are used within the group to designate roles, responsibilities, and levels of authority for specific activities. The matrix format shows all activities associated with one activity. This also ensures that there is only one person accountable for any one task to avoid confusion about who is ultimately in charge or has authority for the work. [34, 35]

Resources.Question: The process of tracking team member performance, providing feedback, resolving issues, and managing team changes to optimize project performance is called:
Resources.Explanation: **Manage Team**â€”The process of tracking team member performance, providing feedback, resolving issues, and managing team changes to optimize project performance. [35, 36]

Resources.Question: Andre is a new project manager of a construction project, which has 105 team members. All project team members are working on a building which has been taken for lease for the project as a part of direct cost. In his first meeting with project sponsor and key stakeholders, he finds that the project has to be extended for another 1 year to meet additional customer needs. The approved change request is already in place for the same. What should Andre do FIRST to know the lease expiration date of the building where the project work is currently getting performed?
Resources.Choice 1: Have a meeting with the previous project manager.
Resources.Choice 4: Review the contractual agreement of the building.
Resources.Explanation: **Resource calendar** specifies when and how long identified physical or team resources will be available during the project. Here, the building under lease is a physical resource for the project. Based on this, he can identify the need, whether lease needs to be renewed. [36, 37]

Resources.Question: Which one of the following is NOT true regarding control resources process?
Resources.Choice 1: Control resource process should be performed continuously in all project phases and throughout the project life cycle.
Resources.Choice 2: Control resources process is concerned with physical resources as well as human resources.
Resources.Choice 3: Control process monitors the resource expenditure.
Resources.Choice 4: Control resources process ensures that resources are used and released according to the plan and project needs.
Resources.Explanation: **Control Resources process is concerned with physical resources such as equipment, materials, facilities, and infrastructure**. Team members are addressed in Manage team process. [38, 39]

Resources.Question: According to Tuckman ladder model that describes team development, the phase in which the team members move on from the project after completing their work is called:
Resources.Explanation: **Adjourning**. In this phase, the team completes the work and moves on from the project. This typically occurs when staff is released from the project as deliverables are completed or as part of the Close Project or Phase process. [39, 40]

Resources.Question: A resource calendar identifies the working days, shifts, start and end of normal business hours, and public holidays and also when each specific resource is available which helps a project manager in controlling the schedule. Such a calendar is an output of:
Resources.Explanation: A **resource calendar** identifies the working days, shifts, start and end of normal business hours, weekends, and public holidays when each specific resource is available. [40]

Resources.Question: Steve is a project manager for developing new robots. Two team members came to him with a dispute regarding who will perform and report the status of a particular task. To resolve this conflict, which document should Steve refer to?
Resources.Explanation: One example of a RAM is a **RACI** (responsible, accountable, consult, and inform) chart. A RACI chart is a useful tool to use to ensure clear assignment of roles and responsibilities when the team consists of internal and external resources. [40, 41]

Resources.Question: During the development of the project management plan of an IT automation project, the project management team decides to build a working environment where self-organizing team can do their work without any centralized control. What needs to be specially taken into consideration while doing resource planning?
Resources.Choice 2: Acquire industry standard subject matter expert from the market.
Resources.Choice 3: Ensure that the project scope is defined in details.
Resources.Choice 4: Appoint a technical architect for playing the role of a project manager.
Resources.Explanation: As per the situation stated in the question, the project management team has decided to adopt agile development approach for project work execution. Agile project teams are generally self-organizing and cross-functional. In these teams, the team functions independently without centralized control. The project manager may not be called a project manager in these teams. Instead, the project manager may adopt Laissez-faire leadership style, allowing team to establish their own goals. In resource planning, successful self-organizing teams consist of **generalized specialists** rather than subject matter experts. [41-43]

Resources.Question: George is a project manager of a healthcare organization. The due date of one of the project deliverables is upcoming, but a team member's performance is negatively impacting the schedule. What should George do?
Resources.Choice 1: Remove the team member from the project.
Resources.Choice 3: Schedule training sessions for the team member to optimize his performance.
Resources.Explanation: Objectives of developing a project team include but are not limited to: Creating a dynamic, cohesive, and collaborative team culture to: (1) improve individual and team productivity, team spirit, and cooperation ; and (2) allow **cross-training and mentoring** between team members to share knowledge and expertise. [44-46]

Resources.Question: You have planned to use four excavators in your underground parking project to finish the project on time. After the first site visit, you discovered that the mobility of four excavators at once is not possible so, you rescheduled your project to work by three excavators only. Such rescheduling caused the project end date to shift. What planning technique did you use?
Resources.Explanation: **Resource leveling**. A technique in which start and finish dates are adjusted based on resource constraints with the goal of balancing the demand for resources with the available supply. Resource leveling can be used when shared or critically required resources are available only at certain times or in limited quantities, or are over-allocated. Resource leveling can often cause the original critical path to change. [46, 47]

Resources.Question: Nancy is working with her project team to obtain an administrative closure of the software development project she is managing. The project was performed exclusively with internal resources provided by the functional leaders. Which of the following is most likely to be the last action taken in this scenario?
Resources.Choice 1: Conducting a survey to measure stakeholder satisfaction.
Resources.Choice 2: Transferring the final product to operations.
Resources.Explanation: Although some of the project team members may be released before the project has been closed, some of the project team should remain to perform the activities associated with the administrative closure of the project. [48, 49]

Resources.Question: Sandy is a project manager who has been assigned to manage a new project. The project needs resources with specific skills from various organization departments. She must identify and agree on available internal human resources, and hire external experts because most organization staff are already assigned to other projects. What should Sandy use FIRST to obtain resources?
Resources.Explanation: An interpersonal and team skill that can be used for Acquire Resources process is **negotiation**. Many projects need to negotiate for required resources. The project manager needs to negotiate with: Functional managers to ensure that the project receives the best resources possible, Other project management teams to appropriately assign or share resources, and External organizations and suppliers. [50, 51]

Resources.Question: You are managing a project of developing a mobile application. The customer adds some new features and asks for a budget update. The new features cannot extend the project schedule for more than 3 months. What should you do next?
Resources.Choice 1: Calculate the project performance using the earned value management method.
Resources.Choice 4: Estimate the required number of additional project resources.
Resources.Explanation: As per the scenario mentioned, the schedule and scope baseline will be affected. The project manager and the project team members should evaluate the impact on other constraints such as **resources**. [52, 53]

Resources.Question: You are a project manager in an organization in which the functional manager transferred some resources you need from your project to another project. What should you do next?
Resources.Choice 1: Negotiate with Functional Manager to assign new resources.
Resources.Choice 2: Escalate this problem to the sponsor.
Resources.Choice 3: Complete the project without these resources.
Resources.Explanation: The project manager should effectively **negotiate** and influence others who are in a position to provide the required team and physical resources for the project. [53, 54]

Resources.Question: You are a project manager of a company, and your project is currently in the execution phase. One of your project teams leaves the site early at 3:00 pm Friday and mistreats his colleagues. You would like to establish clear expectations regarding the acceptable behavior of the team. To avoid such situations, what should you create?
Resources.Explanation: The **team charter** establishes clear expectations regarding acceptable behavior by project team members. [54, 55]

Resources.Question: Emma is a project manager of an IT automation project. The project is in execution and few key stakeholders along with the project sponsor are not happy with performance of the delivery team. In a team meeting, Emma realized that the project team members are working hard and completing tasks on time, but they are struggling to operate the latest software, which caused that the task updates are not getting properly updated in the software on time. What should Emma do to resolve this?
Resources.Choice 1: Review the resource calendar to find a slot for training.
Resources.Choice 2: Raise a change request for updating the training requirements in the resource management plan.
Resources.Choice 3: Capture the lessons learned in the lessons learned register.
Resources.Choice 4: Modify the project team assignment and organizational process assets.
Resources.Explanation: For resolving the current situation, the project team needs to be trained on the new software for which **resource calendar** should be reviewed, which will help the project manager to find a training slot. [55, 56]

Resources.Question: A project manager focuses on systems and structure to accomplish project goals. As a result, the project manager has a strained relationship with the project team. Although the current project is trending to meet project objectives, excessive turnover of the project team threatens the project. For self-improvement, what type of skills should the project manager spend time developing ?
Resources.Explanation: The strained relationship with the project team suggests that the project manager lacks in **leadership skills** to foster better relationships. [56, 57]

Resources.Question: Emma is the project manager of a shopping mall construction project. The project team has been recently hired. It is an enterprise-wide project offering various stakeholders. It is very important for each team member to properly understand and follow the project communication requirements in order to keep the stakeholders engaged and informed. Which of the following tools and techniques can Emma use to ensure that team members properly understand the projectâ€™s communications requirements?
Resources.Explanation: **Training** that involves interaction between learners is a tool and technique to ensure that team members understand project communication requirements. [58, 59]

Risk.Question: The document that contains a list of identified risks along with their nominated risk owners is called:
Risk.Explanation: The **risk register** contains details of individual project risks that have been identified and prioritized, and for which risk responses are required. The risk register identifies the nominated risk owner for each risk [1]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 440.

Risk.Question: When should the project manager plan for risk identification activities?
Risk.Choice 1: During the perform qualitative risk analysis process.
Risk.Choice 2: During the perform quantitative risk analysis process.
Risk.Choice 4: During the plan risk management process.
Risk.Explanation: **Identify risks** is the process of determining what risks can affect the project. Many different stakeholders usually participate in the identify risks process. The process of identify risks is iterative because unknown risks can be discovered throughout the life cycle of the project [2].

Risk.Question: Which of the following estimating techniques takes risk and uncertainty into consideration?
Risk.Explanation: **Three-point estimate** helps us to define an approximate range of an activityâ€™s duration [3]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 244, 245, 724

Risk.Question: While planning for risk management, you and your team agreed to prioritize risk by using a graphical representation of the likelihood of the risk to take place against its effect on a scale of (V.low-Low-Medium-High). Such a tool is called:
Risk.Explanation: Prioritization rules may be specified by the organization in advance of the project and be included in organizational process assets, or they may be tailored to the specific project. Opportunities and threats are represented in a common **probability and impact matrix** using positive definitions of impact for opportunities and negative impact definitions for threats [4]. Descriptive terms (such as very high, high, medium, low, and very low) or numeric values can be used for probability and impact. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 408.

Risk.Question: As you are planning for risk responses, you encountered the risk of 'Increase in taxes on imported materials' so, one of your team members suggested to replace all imported materials by locally manufactured ones. Such response is considered :
Risk.Explanation: **Risk avoidance** is when the project team acts to eliminate the threat or protect the project from its impact. It may be appropriate for high-priority threats with a high probability of occurrence and a large negative impact. Avoidance may involve changing some aspect of the project management plan or changing the objective that is in jeopardy in order to eliminate the threat entirely, reducing its probability of occurrence to zero [5]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443

Risk.Question: A water treatment project experienced delays from lower than anticipated worker productivity, errors in construction, and worse than expected climate. Although these individual risks were previously identified, the combined effects of these realized risks were greater than the individual risk response plans and a critical project deadline was missed. What might have been done differently to plan better for the risks?
Risk.Explanation: **Variability risks** can be addressed using Monte Carlo analysis, with the range of variation reflected in probability distributions, followed by actions to reduce the spread of possible outcomes [6]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 399

Risk.Question: The risk response strategy that deals with opportunities by making sure that the opportunity would materialize to capture the benefit associated with it, is called:
Risk.Explanation: **Exploit**. The exploit strategy may be selected for high-priority opportunities where the organization wants to ensure that the opportunity is realized. This strategy seeks to capture the benefit associated with a particular opportunity by ensuring that it definitely happens, increasing the probability of occurrence to 100% [7]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 444

Risk.Question: During a workshop to study the proposed risk response plans to the identified risks in your project, the majority of your team was tending to choose the option of 'Outsourcing the design of the project' over 'Upgrading to a more advanced design software' for the risk of 'Design mistakes due to project complexity '. You decided to ignore your team's desire and chose to follow your opinion. The strategy you used is called:
Risk.Explanation: **Force/direct**. Pushing oneâ€™s viewpoint at the expense of others; offering only win-lose solutions, usually enforced through a power position to resolve an emergency. This approach often results to a win-lose situation [8]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 349

Risk.Question: Which of the following is Not considered a component of the Risk Management Plan?
Risk.Choice 3: Definitions of Risk Probability and Impacts
Risk.Explanation: The risk management plan is a component of the project management plan that describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed. The risk management plan may include some or all of the following elements: **Risk strategy**, Methodology, Roles and responsibilities, Funding, Timing, **Risk categories**, Stakeholder risk appetite, **Definitions of risk probability and impacts**, Probability and impact matrix, Reporting formats, and Tracking [9]. Figure 11-6. Identify Risks: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 405, 407, 408 & 409

Risk.Question: Albert is a project manager and during the planning phase of his construction project, it came to his knowledge that the project sponsor has removed some important deliverables in several projects over the past years producing a negative cost variance. What should Albert do next?
Risk.Choice 2: Document the issue in the issue log.
Risk.Choice 3: Include the risk in the risk register.
Risk.Explanation: Causing negative cost variance is considered a risk so, the project manager should **include it in the risk register** [10].

Risk.Question: Which of the following is an output of the Identify Risks process that contains information on sources of overall project risk with summary information on identified individual project risks?
Risk.Explanation: The **risk report** presents information on sources of overall project risk, together with summary information on identified individual project risks. The risk report is developed progressively throughout the Project Risk Management process. The results of Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis, Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis, Plan Risk Responses, Implement Risk Responses, and Monitor Risks are also included in the risk report as those processes are completed [11]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 418

Risk.Question: As work progresses in your project, a defined risk owner in your team informed you that the risk he is assigned for has been realized and he would start implementing the agreed risk response. As a project manager, what should you do?
Risk.Choice 3: Raise the issue to upper management.
Risk.Explanation: The **issue log** will help the project manager effectively track and manage issues, ensuring that they are investigated and resolved. The issue log is created for the first time as an output of this process, although issues may happen at any time during the project. The issue log is updated as a result of the monitoring and control activities throughout the projectâ€™s life cycle [12, 13]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 96

Risk.Question: You are a project manager of an IT project. In the middle of your project, you found that the current risk response is ineffective in dealing with the overall project risk. What should you do next?
Risk.Choice 2: Allocate more contingency reserves to account for risks.
Risk.Explanation: **Grouping risks** into categories can lead to the development of more effective risk responses by focusing attention and effort on the areas of highest risk exposure, or by developing generic risk responses to address groups of related risks [14]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 425

Risk.Question: Tina is a project manager of an underground tunnel project. While identifying risks in her project, the project team cannot find an efficient way to reduce the impact and probability or to cover one of the risks. The relevant work is vital to the project so, she cannot simply remove the work package. Also, there is no suitable company to outsource the work to. What is the best action that Tina should take?
Risk.Choice 1: Identify ways to avoid the risk.
Risk.Choice 2: Identify ways to exploit the risk.
Risk.Choice 3: Accept the risk and have contingency reserves.
Risk.Choice 4: Keep looking for ways to mitigate the probability and impact of the risk.
Risk.Explanation: Since there is no suitable company to outsource the work to, the project manager should **accept the risk and have contingency reserves** to handle this risk [15, 16].

Risk.Question: Sara is a project manager of establishing a new retail distribution project. A new risk is discovered during the closing stage of the project. What should Sara do first?
Risk.Choice 1: Ignore the risk; as the customer has already approved the formal deliverables.
Risk.Explanation: A risk can be discovered at any point of time in the project, and all identified risks can be recorded in **risk register** throughout the life cycle of the project; as the process is iterative [16, 17]. C is not correct, because in this situation the risk has been identified, but not occurred. A is incorrect; as per PMI ethics it is the responsibility of the project manager to address such situation at any point in the project life cycle. B is incorrect; as risk management plan has no role here. Here, as per the question, new risk gets discovered during closing so, in this case, the risk register should be updated with information in relation to new risk. Therefore, among all options provided D is the best answer.

Risk.Question: Quality is an example of:-
Risk.Explanation: Quality is degree to which requirements are met. Quality demand changes are always subjective to **technical risk** [17].

Risk.Question: Helen is a project manager of a shopping mall construction project. The tornado alerts that there may be a delay in the shipments of the main materials needed for the project that would affect the project schedule. What should Helen do next?
Risk.Explanation: In this situation, the risk has been activated, but not yet occurred. Thus, option D is ruled out. Option A is also ruled out here; as in this scenario the risk has been activated for natural calamity. Option B is close, but the question states that the project schedule will be impacted if such risk occurs so, in this kind of scenario, the review of risk management plan may not be the ideal choice. By considering elimination rule, C becomes the best answer because the question has keywords like \tornado alerts\". Further
Risk: C is the best answer. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 445"

Risk.Question: Which of the following tools might be used to support selection of the best of several alternative courses of action that would account for the monetary value of each option?
Risk.Explanation: **Decision trees** are used to support selection of the best of several alternative courses of action. Alternative paths through the project are shown in the decision tree using branches representing different decisions or events, each of which can have associated costs and related individual project risks (including both threats and opportunities) [20]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 435

Risk.Question: Assume that you are planning for risk responses and one of the risks you are working on is that 5% of your products might have defects so, you decided to run an additional test before delivering the products. Such response is considered :
Risk.Explanation: In risk **mitigation**, action is taken to reduce the probability of occurrence and/or impact of a threat. Early mitigation action is often more effective than trying to repair the damage after the threat has occurred. Adopting less complex processes, conducting more tests, or choosing a more stable seller are examples of mitigation actions [21, 22]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443.

Risk.Question: Robert is a project manager of a governmental project which has top-secret characteristics. The project has been progressing as planned and suddenly one of his project team members informs him that the project has faced an unexpected problem which was not included in the risk register. What should Robert do first?
Risk.Explanation: As the problem has already occurred, the first action that the project manager should take is to address the risk by **creating a workaround**. Once the issue is addressed, the project manager may need to re-evaluate his risk identification process, look for unexpected effects of the problem, inform management, update the risk management plan, create a fallback plan, and take corrective and preventive actions [22, 23].

Risk.Question: Graham has been recently assigned to manage developing a diesel engine project. Before assembling the product, Graham decided to create a prototype to ensure that the stakeholders will accept it. What Graham thought about resembles which type of risk strategies?
Risk.Explanation: In risk **mitigation**, action is taken to reduce the probability of occurrence and/or impact of a threat. Early mitigation action is often more effective than trying to repair the damage after the threat has occurred. Adopting less complex processes, conducting more tests, or choosing a more stable seller are examples of mitigation actions [23, 24]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443

Risk.Question: Your project is half way through and you are concerned by the identified risks as well as the effectiveness of the risk management plan in dealing with them. What should you do?
Risk.Explanation: **Risk Review**. A meeting to examine and document the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with overall project risk and with identified individual project risks [24, 25]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 721

Risk.Question: Monte Carlo Analysis is a risk management technique that is used for conducting a quantitative analysis of risks. This mathematical technique was developed in 1940, by an atomic nuclear scientist named Stanislaw Ulam. It's meant to be used to analyze the impact of risks on your project. Monte Carlo analysis is a form of:
Risk.Explanation: **Simulations** are typically performed using a Monte Carlo analysis [25, 26]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 433

Risk.Question: Midway through the project, the project management team decides to reassess few risks which they think are no longer valid. Risk reassessment is done as part of which of the following processes ?
Risk.Explanation: **Risk reassessment** is performed as part of the monitor risks process. Such project risk reassessments should be regularly scheduled and may result in the closure of outdated risks [26, 27]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 457

Risk.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a construction project. You and your team have already identified a list of potential risks along with the best responses to reduce either the effect or the probability of occurrence. The agreed upon risk responses are carried out during which process:
Risk.Explanation: **Implement Risk Responses** is the process of implementing agreed-upon risk response plans. The key benefit of this process is that it ensures that agreed-upon risk responses are executed as planned in order to address overall project risk exposure, minimize individual project threats, and maximize individual project opportunities [27, 28]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 449.

Risk.Question: You are assigned to help in developing the risk register in a project that your company has not executed such before. Part of your role is to use a data gathering technique to help identify realistic risks. You choose to hold meetings with:
Risk.Explanation: To undertake risk identification, the project team may conduct a specialized meeting (often called a risk workshop). On larger projects, it may be appropriate to invite the project sponsor, **subject matter experts** [28, 29]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 416.

Risk.Question: Robinson is managing 2 projects which have the same strategic organizational importance. However, because of budget constraints, only 1 project can be picked. There are some uncertainties and risk associated with the 2 projects. What tool/technique should Robinson use to decide which project to pick?
Risk.Explanation: **Decision trees** are used to support selection of the best of several alternative courses of action. Alternative paths through the project are shown in the decision tree using branches representing different decisions or events, each of which can have associated costs and related individual project risks (including both threats and opportunities). The end-points of branches in the decision tree represent the outcome from following that particular path, which can be negative or positive. The decision tree is evaluated by calculating the expected monetary value of each branch, allowing the optimal path to be selected [29, 30]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 435

Risk.Question: During the last risk review meeting, one of the project team proposed a more efficient response to a certain risk, and during consultation with the rest of the team you agreed to implement the new response instead of the old one. As a project manager, what document should you update?
Risk.Explanation: The **risk register** is updated with information on individual project risks generated during the Monitor Risks process. This may include adding new risks, updating outdated risks or risks that were realized, updating risk responses, and so forth [31, 32]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 458.

Risk.Question: You are managing a software development project. During a review, you noticed that the system had less functionality than planned at the critical review and many errors were detected. Which tool/technique should you use during the Monitor Risk process?
Risk.Explanation: **Technical performance analysis** compares technical accomplishments during project execution to the schedule of technical achievement. It requires the definition of objective, quantifiable measures of technical performance, which can be used to compare actual results against targets. Such technical performance measures may include weight, transaction times, number of delivered defects, storage capacity, etc. Deviation can indicate the potential impact of threats or opportunities [32, 33]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 456

Risk.Question: Richard is the project manager of a hotel renovation project and during the course of his project, Richard faced some problems that were not taken into consideration at the planning stage, moreover, these problems jeopardized the project success; as it took a while to agree to solutions and implement them. Which process should have Richard performed with more caution?
Risk.Explanation: **Identify Risks** is the process of identifying individual project risks as well as sources of overall project risk, and documenting their characteristics. The key benefit of this process is the documentation of existing individual project risks and the sources of overall project risk. It also brings together information so the project team can respond appropriately to identified risks [33, 34]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 409

Risk.Question: Nancy is a project manager of a building a sports stadium project in her organization. As her organization has a low experience in sports' equipment, she outsources the supplying process to an external vendor. During the course of the project, the vendor informs Nancy of a possible delay of 5 days in the final delivery. Those 5 days of delay are considered :
Risk.Explanation: **Secondary risks** are risks that arise as a direct result of implementing a risk response [34, 35]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 439

Risk.Question: A performing organization who was known for their delivery on time is having a problem in meeting deadlines in recent times. The project team anticipated this as a risk and identified the risk in the risk register with suitable response plan. As expected, the performing organization delivered 2 weeks late. What should be done first to handle this situation?
Risk.Choice 1: Inform the stakeholders about the delay.
Risk.Explanation: Here in this situation, the risk has become an issue so, implementation of previously agreed-upon risk response plan is the best action required to be taken care at first. As per the question, since risk response plan already exists, responding to the risk by **implementing planned risk responses** is the best choice [35, 36]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 449

Risk.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a mega project and right now you are planning for risk responses for project risks that have been identified by your team. One of these risks is the adverse climate conditions that might hinder the progress of the project. After a long session with your team, you could not find any solution to that risk except to assign a contingency reserve to be used in case of any losses due to such risk. This response is considered risk:
Risk.Explanation: Risk **acceptance** acknowledges the existence of a threat, but no proactive action is taken. This strategy may be appropriate for low-priority threats, and it may also be adopted where it is not possible or cost-effective to address a threat in any other way. Acceptance can be either active or passive. The most common active acceptance strategy is to establish a contingency reserve, including amounts of time, money, or resources to handle the threat if it occurs. Passive acceptance involves no proactive action apart from periodic review of the threat to ensure that it does not change significantly [36, 37]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443

Risk.Question: Richard is managing a marketing project in his organization. Because of the delay of the workers' expenses, they made a strike which caused a delay in the delivery of an important item. What should Richard do next?
Risk.Explanation: The project manager should **implement the response plan** because of the strike made by the project team members that caused a delay in the delivery of the important item [38, 39].

Risk.Question: Richard is managing a bridge construction project. He has been waiting for some material resources from his supplier. He wants to implement a contingency plan to buy these resources and keep the project on track as a way to avoid delays. Which of the following includes the criteria that triggers the use of a contingency plan?
Risk.Explanation: The **risk register** is updated when appropriate risk responses are chosen and agreed upon. Updates to the risk register may include but are not limited to: Contingency plans and risk triggers that call for their execution [39, 40]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 448

Risk.Question: The risk breakdown structure (RBS) helps the project team consider the full range of sources from which individual project risks that may arise. The second level of RBS includes regulatory and legislation. In which category are these risks included?
Risk.Explanation: Figure 11-4. **Risk Breakdown Structure** (RBS) [40, 41]. PMBOK Guide, 6th Edition, Page 406.

Risk.Question: David is the project manager of a new technology development project. Currently, he is engaged in a risk review and analysis meeting with his core technical team. The main agenda of the meeting is to convert those risks that may arise due to market conditions and the future developments in regulatory frameworks into the known-unknown risks and develop strategic response plans whenever applicable. What type of risk has been addressed here?
Risk.Explanation: **Ambiguity risk**. Uncertainty exists about what might happen in the future. Areas of the project where imperfect knowledge might affect the projectâ€™s ability to achieve its objectives include: elements of the requirement or technical solution, future developments in regulatory frameworks, or inherent systemic complexity in the project [41, 42]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 398

Risk.Question: During the initiation phase, identifying stakeholders is a key to any project success. What should a project manager do after analyzing the project's stakeholders?
Risk.Choice 1: Obtain project charter approval from the sponsor.
Risk.Choice 4: Identify high level risks, assumptions, and constraints.
Risk.Explanation: Domain I) Initiating Task 3 Perform stakeholder analysis using appropriate tools and techniques in order to align expectations and gain support for the project. Task 4 **Identify high level risks, assumptions, and constraints** based on the current environment, organizational factors, historical data, and expert judgment, in order to propose an implementation strategy [42, 43]. PMI PMP Examination Content Outline â€“ June 2015

Risk.Question: While planning for risk responses in your project, you and your team could not find a proper response to one of the proposed risks so, you decided to contact a fellow senior project manager to ask for advice. What you did is one of the tools and techniques used in Plan Risk Response process called:
Risk.Explanation: **Expert Judgment**. Judgment provided based upon expertise in an application area, knowledge area, discipline, industry, etc., as appropriate for the activity being performed. Such expertise may be provided by any group or person with specialized education, knowledge, skill, experience, or training [43, 44]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 706

Risk.Question: Your company is sponsoring a clothing gallery for raising fund for an Orphanage . However, your company cannot afford to pay the $50,000 award if someone catches the lucky moment in a specific seller area. Therefore, the company decides to take an insurance policy in the event if someone exists there. Which of the following risk response strategies has been referred in the given scenario?
Risk.Explanation: The use of **insurance to shift the negative impact of a risk**, in this case the payment of $50,000, is an example of risk transference [44, 45]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443

Risk.Question: The procurement manager of an IT project informed the project manager that the cost of the UPS devices may exceed the budgeted amount. The project should have a UPS devices delivery within the next month. What should the project manager do FIRST?
Risk.Choice 1: Negotiate with the supplier of the devices.
Risk.Choice 2: Request a quote from another supplier.
Risk.Choice 4: Contact the project sponsor to get more funds.
Risk.Explanation: The risk is already identified and analyzed. The next step is to **plan risk response** [45, 46].

Risk.Question: You are managing a manufacturing project. You have just started prioritizing individual project risks for further analysis. One of the stakeholders expressed a concern that the existing information about individual project risks may not be accurate and reliable. What is the best action you should take?
Risk.Choice 1: Capture the concern in the stakeholder register.
Risk.Choice 2: Perform a risk data quality assessment.
Risk.Choice 3: Perform the identify risks process again.
Risk.Choice 4: Conduct a risk probability and impact assessment.
Risk.Explanation: **Risk data quality assessment** evaluates the degree to which the data about individual project risks is accurate and reliable as a basis for qualitative risk analysis. The use of low-quality risk data may lead to a qualitative risk analysis that is of little use to the project. If data quality is unacceptable, it may be necessary to gather better data. Risk data quality may be assessed via a questionnaire measuring the projectâ€™s stakeholder perceptions of various characteristics, which may include completeness, objectivity, relevancy, and timeliness. A weighted average of selected data quality characteristics can then be generated to give an overall quality score [46, 47]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 423

Risk.Question: Vivian is managing a project of developing a robotic window washing system. The project sponsor is highly concerned that the project may run over budget and asks Vivian to confirm that this is not going to happen. In order to mitigate the sponsor's concerns, what should Vivian do?
Risk.Choice 2: Create the Probability and Impact Matrix.
Risk.Explanation: **SWOT analysis**. This technique examines the project from each of the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT) perspectives. For risk identification, it is used to increase the breadth of identified risks by including internally generated risks [48, 49]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 415

Risk.Question: On your project to construct a multistory garage project, you are in the process of planning risk responses to the identified risks. One of the identified risks is the housekeeping of the site. Your team proposed to hire a housekeeping company. Such a proposal is considered :
Risk.Explanation: **Transfer** involves shifting ownership of a threat to a third party to manage the risk and to bear the impact if the threat occurs [49, 50]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443.

Risk.Question: Which of the following documents can be considered an input to the Define Scope process?
Risk.Explanation: The **risk register** contains response strategies that may affect the project scope, such as reducing or changing project and product scope to avoid or mitigate a risk [50, 51]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 152

Risk.Question: A project team is working on a risk response strategy by evaluating every risk and coming up with suitable response strategies. However, one particular risk with a negative impact cannot be avoided or mitigated. Furthermore, there is no way to transfer risk by outsourcing or buying insurance. What is the best the team can do about the risk?
Risk.Choice 3: Treat it as a secondary risk and update it in the Risk Register.
Risk.Choice 4: Share the risk by allocating ownership to a third party.
Risk.Explanation: The question suggests that the team has already explored all the alternatives so, option (Revisit the Risk Response Strategy) would not provide any further solution. In this case, the best strategy is to **accept the risk** and, if possible, plan for a contingency to be implemented if risk occurs. Option (Share the risk by allocating ownership to a third party) is a strategy for positive risks or opportunities. Option (Treat it as a secondary risk and update it in the Risk Register) is not true; as a secondary risk is an outcome of implementing a risk response strategy [51, 52].

Risk.Question: You have finished identifying potential risks to the project and you want to document these risks in order to further categorize them and assign potential risk owners as well as risk responses. Where should you document such data?
Risk.Explanation: The **risk register** captures details of identified individual project risks. The results of Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis, Plan Risk Responses, Implement Risk Responses, and Monitor Risks are recorded in the risk register as those processes are conducted throughout the project. The risk register may contain limited or extensive risk information depending on project variables such as size and complexity. The content of the risk register may include but is not limited to: List of identified risks, Potential risk owners and List of potential risk responses [53, 54]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 417.

Risk.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a software development project, and you discovered that some team members lack the knowledge of an advanced programming language that would slightly decrease the project duration. The cost of giving trainings to those members would require funding that you cannot manage right now so, you decided to use another programming language that all members can work with. What you did is considered risk .............
Risk.Explanation: **Risk avoidance** is when the project team acts to eliminate the threat or protect the project from its impact. It may be appropriate for high-priority threats with a high probability of occurrence and a large negative impact. Avoidance may involve changing some aspect of the project management plan or changing the objective that is in jeopardy in order to eliminate the threat entirely, reducing its probability of occurrence to zero. The risk owner may also take action to isolate the project objectives from the riskâ€™s impact if it were to occur. Examples of avoidance actions may include removing the cause of a threat, extending the schedule, changing the project strategy, or reducing scope. Some risks can be avoided by clarifying requirements, obtaining information, improving communication, or acquiring expertise [54-56]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443

Risk.Question: The document that shows the different types of potential risks under wide range of risk sources in a hierarchical representation is called:
Risk.Explanation: **Risk categories**. Provide a means for grouping individual project risks. A common way to structure risk categories is with a risk breakdown structure (RBS), which is a hierarchical representation of potential sources of risk. An RBS helps the project team consider the full range of sources from which individual project risks may arise. This can be useful when identifying risks or when categorizing identified risks. The organization may have a generic RBS to be used for all projects, or there may be several RBS frameworks for different types of projects, or the project may develop a tailored RBS. Where an RBS is not used, an organization may use a custom risk categorization framework, which may take the form of a simple list of categories or a structure based on project objectives [56, 57]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 405.

Risk.Question: Assume that you are managing a complex project that has a team spread over more than four countries. The communication software you wish to use in your project is not functioning quite well in two countries you have teams in due to technical issues so, you decided to use a whole different software for communication with slightly less data transfer speed. The risk response strategy you used is called:
Risk.Explanation: **Risk avoidance** is when the project team acts to eliminate the threat or protect the project from its impact. It may be appropriate for high-priority threats with a high probability of occurrence and a large negative impact. Avoidance may involve changing some aspect of the project management plan or changing the objective that is in jeopardy in order to eliminate the threat entirely, reducing its probability of occurrence to zero [58, 59]. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 443.

Procurement.Question: While planning for the procurements of a mega project, an experienced project manager would compare between various vendors and suppliers based on commonly used selection methods such as: least cost, highest technical proposal score, or sole source. All these methods and more fall under a specific tool used while planning for procurement management. This tool is called:
Procurement.Explanation: Since competitive selection methods may require sellers to invest a large amount of time and resources upfront, it is a good practice to include the evaluation method in the procurement documents so bidders know how they will be evaluated. Commonly used selection methods include the following: Least cost, Qualifications only, Quality-based/highest technical proposal score, Quality and cost-based, Sole source and Fixed budget. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 473, 474

Procurement.Question: Assume that you are the project manager in a seller company and the client is asking you to provide a quotation for a specific work that your company will perform for that client. What document should you ask the client to provide you in order to assess the required work?
Procurement.Explanation: Terms and conditions of the contract and the procurement statement of work (SOW) become key inputs to many of the seller’s management processes. The contract can actually contain the inputs (e.g., major deliverables, key milestones, cost objectives) or it can limit the project team’s options (for example, buyer approval of staffing decisions is often required on IT integration projects). PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 462

Procurement.Question: Simon is managing a project of developing a prototype diesel engine. The parts supplier has not been supplying quality parts even after a lot of rejections and warnings. Simon has lost hope that this supplier will ever deliver the quality deliverables. What is the best action that Simon should take?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Continue negotiating with the supplier until the desire results are obtained.
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Accept the deliverables because there is no use in negotiating further with her supplier.
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Review the contract termination in the terms of the contract and take the necessary steps to terminate the contract.
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Use alternative dispute resolution techniques.
Procurement.Explanation: Since there are a lot of rejections and warnings, this means that this vendor has not improved his performance so, there is nothing to negotiate about. Also, there is no conflict between the project manager and the vendor so, alternative dispute resolution would not be effective. The best thing to do is to terminate the contract. The project manager should review the contract termination statement in the contract to take the necessary steps to terminate the contract.

Procurement.Question: A contract's clause does not allow for appeals in courts of law based on performance. What type of contracts has been referred in the given scenario?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Cost Plus Award Fee Contract (CPAF)
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Fixed Price with Economic Price Adjustments (FPEPA)
Procurement.Explanation: Cost Plus Award Fee Contract (CPAF). A category of contract that involves payments to the seller for all legitimate actual costs incurred for completed work, plus an award fee representing seller profit. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 703

Procurement.Question: The process of documenting project procurement decisions, specifying the approach and identifying potential sellers is called:
Procurement.Explanation: Plan Procurement Management is the process of documenting project procurement decisions, specifying the approach and identifying potential sellers. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 466

Procurement.Question: What would be the best contract type to be used for a mega project that would last for at least 6 years in which the seller would like to protect his profit against currency exchange rates for imported items as well as inflation?
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Fixed Price with Economic Price Adjustments (FPEPA)
Procurement.Explanation: Fixed price with economic price adjustments (FPEPA). This type is used whenever the seller’s performance period spans a considerable period of years, or if the payments are made in a different currency. It is a fixed-price contract, but with a special provision allowing for predefined final adjustments to the contract price due to changed conditions, such as inflation changes or cost increases (or decreases) for specific commodities. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 471.

Procurement.Question: At the midway of the project, the sole provider has delayed the delivery of the materials for the project that lead to an effect on the project schedule. Keeping the supplier with the same delivery rate will provide further delays, and replacing the supplier will lead to cost overrun. What will be your next step?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Work with the supplier to solve the problem.
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Escalate the problem to procurement department.
Procurement.Explanation: As SOLE PROVIDER is mentioned, the project manager should work with the supplier to solve the problem.

Procurement.Question: Melody is managing an IT project. What estimating technique should she use to estimate a project using a firm fixed price contract?
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Program Evaluation and Review Technique
Procurement.Explanation: Bottom-up estimating is a method of estimating project duration or cost by aggregating the estimates of the lowerlevel components of the WBS. When an activity’s duration cannot be estimated with a reasonable degree of confidence, the work within the activity is decomposed into more detail. The detail durations are estimated. These estimates are then aggregated into a total quantity for each of the activity’s durations. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 202

Procurement.Question: George has just started a new project in a marketing organization. Due to COVID-19 crisis, the organization went bankrupt and was sold to another organization. The project which George was managing has been terminated. What should George do next?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Review the project charter; as the details for the buyout are listed there.
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Complete closed procurements as part of the control procurements process.
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Review the project management plan for closing the project.
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Begin filing all of the documents as part of lessons learned.
Procurement.Explanation: The project manager should ensure that the closed procurements are completed as part of the control procurement process and then move to the close project/phase process.

Procurement.Question: You are the project manager of a power plant project in which most of the works shall be outsourced to subcontractors. Your main concern is the quality of work performed by those subcontractors. Which process should you pay most attention to in order to ensure the project meets its requirements?
Procurement.Explanation: Control Procurements is the process of managing procurement relationships; monitoring contract performance, and making changes and corrections as appropriate; and closing out contracts. The key benefit of this process is that it ensures that both the seller’s and buyer’s performance meet the project’s requirements according to the terms of the legal agreement. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 492

Procurement.Question: While reviewing the market suppliers, a professional project manager should always ensure that the proposal selected will offer the best quality for the services required by defining a source selection criteria. Such criteria is an output of which process?
Procurement.Explanation: Figure 12-2. Plan Procurement Management: Inputs, Tools & Techniques, and Outputs PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 466.

Procurement.Question: Jack is managing a commercial project. Midway into the project execution, one of the project team members approaches him with concerns that the quality of the project deliverables is low. How should this concern be verified?
Procurement.Explanation: An inspection is the examination of a work product to determine if it conforms to documented standards. The results of inspections generally include measurements and may be conducted at any level. The results of a single activity can be inspected, or the final product of the project can be inspected. Inspections may be called reviews, peer reviews, audits, or walkthroughs. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 330

Procurement.Question: Edson is a project manager of an IT project. The work associated to 3 work packages has been allocated to a preferred vendor. During the middle of the project, a group of experts appointed by Edson are conducting the structured review of work being performed by the preferred vendor as well as of the procurements processes being followed in the process. Which of the following processes is getting executed?
Procurement.Explanation: As per the given scenario, the experts are engaged in procurement audit and inspection activities, and both audit and inspection are valid tools and techniques for control procurements process. Audit is the structured review of the procurement process, whereas inspection is the structured review of the work being done by the contractor. Thus, among all options provided, D is the best answer. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 498

Procurement.Question: You are the project manager of a water treatment plant project that has a lot of work to be outsourced as your company lacks the capability to perform on its own so, you prepare a statement of work for the outsourced works along with source selection criteria. These documents fall under an output of the Plan Procurement process called:
Procurement.Explanation: Procurement documentation provides a written record used in reaching the legal agreement, and may include older documents predating the current project. Procurement documentation can include: Bid documents, Procurement statement of work, Independent cost estimates and Source selection criteria. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 485

Procurement.Question: Assume that you are the project manager of a water treatment plant project in which there is a complex part that you decided to outsource to a specialist subcontractor. After selecting a number of possible subcontractors, you received multiple inquiries from them about the scope of work. You want to make sure that all subcontractors have a clear understanding of the scope of work prior to their offer submittals. What tool/technique should assist you to do so?
Procurement.Explanation: Bidder conferences (also called contractor conferences, vendor conferences, and pre-bid conferences) are meetings between the buyer and prospective sellers prior to proposal submittal. They are used to ensure that all prospective bidders have a clear and common understanding of the procurement and no bidders receive preferential treatment. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 487

Procurement.Question: You are the project manager of a mega software development project and your team is quite large and the project work requires conducting several meetings at the same time. The workspace assigned to your project in the headquarter will not contain such number. As a project manager, what should you do?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Negotiate with the sponsor for additional workspace.
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Raise the issue to upper management.
Procurement.Explanation: The use of virtual teams creates new possibilities when acquiring project team members. Virtual teams can be defined as groups of people with a shared goal who fulfill their roles with little or no time spent meeting face to face. The availability of communication technology such as email, audio conferencing, social media, web-based meetings, and video conferencing has made virtual teams feasible. The virtual team model makes it possible to: Save the expense of offices and all physical equipment needed for employees. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 333.

Procurement.Question: Alfred is managing a research project that is near completion. Some of the project deliverables have been contracted to vendors. He begins to close the project and wants to make sure that all the necessary activities for the project closure are properly completed. Which of the following activities would you NOT perform as part of this process?
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Measuring the satisfaction of the stakeholders.
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Ensuring that all costs are charged to the project.
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Reviewing the project exit criteria.
Procurement.Explanation: Close Project or Phase is the process of finalizing all activities for the project, phase, or contract. The key benefits of this process are the project or phase information is archived, the planned work is completed, and organizational resources are released to pursue new endeavors. All the choices EXCEPT closing procurements with vendors which represent activities performed during project closure. Closing procurements is an input to the close project or phase process. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 633, 634

Procurement.Question: Which of the following is NOT considered a bid document?
Procurement.Explanation: Table 12-1. Comparison of Procurement Documentation PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 481

Procurement.Question: Matthew is managing a water treatment plant. While doing the estimation, he realizes that he will need 10 resources for 8 months. After negotiating with the functional manager, Matthew could get only 4 resources and according to the organizational policy, he can hire only 4 resources every 8 months. What should Matthew do next?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Negotiate with external organizations and suppliers.
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Negotiate with the functional manager to get more 4 resources.
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Request his project customer to get more resources.
Procurement.Explanation: The project manager should negotiate with external organizations and suppliers; as he has already negotiated with the functional manager and could not get the required resources.

Procurement.Question: The project manager is not happy with the cost estimates provided by 3 prospective sellers. They are far away from what he actually expected. He decides to have another meeting with all perspective sellers. Before going for the meeting, what should he review?
Procurement.Explanation: The project manager should review procurement SOW before going for the meeting. Significant differences in estimation can be an indication that the procurement SOW was deficient, ambiguous, or that the prospective sellers misunderstood the SOW. If we analyze the question, we can draw an assumption that cost estimates of the sellers are not matching with the independent cost estimate of the buyer. Procurement SOW should clearly state how independent cost estimate was derived. Among all given options, reviewing the procurement SOW before the meeting is the best answer. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 479

Procurement.Question: You are managing a manufacturing project. During a group activity to identify an input to the plan procurement management process, a few participants did not agree with the ranking of the compliance related items. What tool/technique should you use to resolve this issue?
Procurement.Explanation: Requirements Documentation is an input of the plan procurement management process and one of the tools in collect requirement process is nominal group technique. The nominal group technique enhances brainstorming with a voting process used to rank the most useful ideas for further brainstorming or for prioritization. The nominal group technique is a structured form of brainstorming consisting of four steps: A question or problem is posed to the group. Each person silently generates and writes down their ideas - The moderator writes down the ideas on a flip chart until all ideas are recorded - Each recorded idea is discussed until all group members have a clear understanding - Individuals vote privately to prioritize the ideas, usually using a scale of 1 – 5, with 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest. Voting may take place in many rounds to reduce and focus in on ideas. After each round, the votes are tallied and the highest scoring ideas are selected. PMBOK guide-6th-edition pages 144 & 145

Procurement.Question: As you are preparing the contract to be signed between your organization and a contractor to build a new headquarter, your design has not been finalized yet so, you want to include a clause that helps in resolving any conflict that may arise due to disputes in case you could not reach an agreement on the changes values. Which of the following should you include?
Procurement.Choice 1: A) Allow 50% of the changes not to be contested.
Procurement.Choice 2: B) Seek advice from alternative dispute resolution (ADR).
Procurement.Choice 3: C) Hire a change control board (CCB).
Procurement.Choice 4: D) Handle all changes through project management office (PMO).
Procurement.Explanation: Claims are documented, processed, monitored, and managed throughout the contract life cycle, usually in accordance with the terms of the contract. If the parties themselves do not resolve a claim, it may have to be handled in accordance with alternative dispute resolution (ADR) typically following procedures established in the contract. Settlement of all claims and disputes through negotiation is the preferred method. PMBOK guide-6th-edition page 498

Procurement.Question: Luiz is managing an oil refinement project. He is going to have a meeting with the project team to evaluate vendor proposals.
